Project Description  Two  projects  are  presented  together  for  Board  consideration.  The 
Tsunami-affected Areas Rebuilding Project (TAARP) contributes to the 
Government’s  overall  rebuilding  efforts  following  the  tsunami  in 
December 2004. Post-tsunami efforts will focus on rebuilding roads and 
other  coastal-belt  community  infrastructure  and  shelter,  restoring 
livelihoods, providing coastline protection damaged by the tsunami; and 
facilitating law and governance measures and safeguards.  
 
The  North  East  Community  Restoration  and  Development  Project  II 
(NECORD-II),  programmed  for  2005,  continues  the  Government’s 
rehabilitation program for the conflict-affected areas of the Northern and 
Eastern provinces. Post-conflict rehabilitation will address basic needs in 
the  conflict-affected  areas  through  health,  education,  irrigation, 
agriculture,  community  development,  institutional  infrastructure,  and 
income-generation subprojects.  
   
Rationale  On 26 December 2004, a 9.0-magnitude earthquake near Sumatra sent 
several  tsunami  waves  that  struck  over  two  thirds  of  Sri  Lanka’s 
coastline and caused catastrophic destruction; more than 31,000 people 
in Sri Lanka died and thousands more are still missing. Another 440,000 
people are displaced, with the tsunami-affected population estimated at 
between 1 and 2 million, out of a total population of about 19 million.

ii 
  Nearly 100,000 houses were destroyed during the tsunami and another 
46,000 were damaged. Infrastructure and fishing industry assets such as 
boats were damaged or lost. About 60% of the damage occurred on the 
east and northeast coasts.  
 
  A joint tsunami needs assessment, in cooperation with the Government 
and the Task Force for Rebuilding the Nation, was undertaken by ADB, 
the World Bank, and the Japan Bank for International Cooperation, in 
concert with United Nations agencies. Tsunami-related financing needs 
for rebuilding are estimated to be approximately $1.5 billion. In the short 
term, the majority of resources are required for housing, transportation, 
institutional  and  community  infrastructure,  livelihood  restoration  for 
fishermen  and  small-scale  farmers,  and  small  and  micro-enterprise 
assistance.  
 
  The coastal areas of the Northern and Eastern provinces have only 
recently begun to emerge from the devastating effects of nearly 20 years 
of civil conflict when the tsunami hit. The conflict left over 65,000 dead, 
several  times  as  many  people  disabled,  and  nearly  800,000  people 
displaced  from  their  homes.  A  large  percentage  of  people  directly 
affected by the conflict still suffer from a lack of basic infrastructure and 
social services. A cease-fire agreement signed by the Government and 
the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam 3 years before the tsunami hit had 
enabled a period of reconciliation and restoration in the North East. 
However, many villages and much of the coastal infrastructure that had 
been rebuilt after the cease-fire were destroyed by the tsunami. Many 
other assets that had withstood the conflict were lost in the tsunami.  
 
  After the cease-fire, a comprehensive conflict needs assessment was 
presented  to  the  international  community  at  the  Sri  Lanka 
Reconstruction  and  Development  Conference  held  in  Tokyo  in  June 
2003. The needs assessment estimated that about $3 billion would be 
required for relief, rehabilitation, and reconstruction. Of this $2 billion, 
about $780 million was identified for immediate needs, and about $1.2 
billion was identified for medium-term needs. To date, the international 
community  has  committed  about  $700 million––to  address  both 
immediate and medium-term needs. This leaves at least $80 million of 
the immediate needs unmet.

iii
  The pre-tsunami conditions and the situation in the North East make it 
difficult to demarcate tsunami- and conflict-related rebuilding efforts. The 
tsunami needs assessment emphasized the importance of key guiding 
principles—such  as  conflict  sensitivity,  subsidiarity,  community 
empowerment,  transparency,  multi-hazard  risk  management,  and 
coordination  between  stakeholders—during  the  development  of  a 
comprehensive  recovery  strategy.  The  international  community  has 
responded generously with pledges of tsunami assistance. However, 
provision  of  significant  assistance  to  tsunami-affected  people  may 
produce tensions if it is perceived that different parts of the country or 
ethnic groups are receiving more than their fair share of reconstruction 
funds, or if other people who are in poverty, or internally displaced from 
the conflict, feel they are being forgotten. By providing assistance at the 
same time and with a similar delivery framework and policies to both 
tsunami- and conflict-affected areas, the risk of creating a perception of 
unequal  treatment  of  people  affected  by  either  calamity  will  be 
minimized.  
 
  Recognizing the urgent needs and the social services and infrastructure 
lost as a result of the tsunami and the 20-year conflict, both projects 
have been processed under ADB’s Disaster and Emergency Assistance 
Policy.  TAARP  will  complement  and  augment  other  projects  in  the 
tsunami-affected  areas,  benefiting  from  the  current  extensive 
coordination  mechanisms  established  among  external  parties. 
NECORD-II also coordinates well with other projects planned or ongoing 
in the North East and will reinforce the perception that the international 
community remains involved with and supports the peace process.  The 
Project will also confirm ADB’s leading role in rehabilitation and peace 
building operations in the North East, the country’s most impoverished 
and vulnerable region, which was also hit particularly hard by the effects 
of the tsunami.  
   
TAARP   The objective of TAARP is to rapidly improve the living conditions and 
Objectives and  well-being  of  a  significant  number  of  people  in  the  tsunami-affected 
Scope  areas  by  restoring  basic  social  infrastructure,  community  and  public 
services, and livelihoods. TAARP will address the needs of tsunami-
affected people through numerous subprojects in a variety of sectors 
selected and formulated in response to requests from tsunami-affected 
people and the Government. Other subprojects will be designed as part 
of the restoration and expansion of ongoing ADB interventions in order 
to  address  tsunami  damage  and  provide  further  environmental 
protection. Governance, anti-corruption and legal empowerment are also 
addressed.

iv 
  TAARP focuses on the highest priority sectors in the tsunami-affected 
areas  for  which  ADB  assistance  is  most  appropriate,  based  on  the 
tsunami  needs  assessments  and  reflecting  consultations  with  the 
Government and other stakeholders. TAARP components include road 
rebuilding  and  rehabilitation,  North  East  coastal  community 
development,  livelihood  restoration,  water  supply  and  sanitation, 
Southern  Province  reconstruction,  coastal  resources  protection,  and 
North East community restoration and development. A legal assistance, 
governance,  and  anticorruption  component  will  help  the  Government 
and tsunami-affected people to resolve legal and documentary issues, 
such as replacing lost identification cards, titles, and certificates. This 
component will also help the Government to confront the risk of an 
increase in corruption that may follow the influx of foreign assistance 
following the tsunami and will support decentralized dispute resolution 
for tsunami victims.

Implementation  Both projects will be implemented through project management units 
Arrangements  (PMUs) already established under other ongoing loans in the portfolio, 
except for the governance component. Each PMU will address a need 
according to its present strength and area of coverage. The PMUs will 
generally be responsible to different executing agencies, according to 
the existing arrangements of their parent loan projects.  
 
  A National Project Coordination Committee chaired by the Secretary, 
Ministry of Finance and Planning, will be established to provide oversight 
and coordination. Members will come from the Task Force for Rebuilding 
the Nation, the Ministry of Justice and Judicial Affairs, the Ministry of 
Defense, other ministries, departments, and agencies responsible for 
tsunami--related  reconstruction  and  rehabilitation,  ADB;  the  chief 
secretaries of the Southern and North East Provincial Councils; ADB 
project directors; and others as appropriate. The committee will meet at 
least  quarterly  and  oversee  overall  project  coordination  and 
implementation at the national level.  
 
  To  ensure  beneficiary  participation  during  project  preparation  and 
implementation, sector subprojects will generally be prepared for and 
approved by a provincial project coordination committee. The North East 
Provincial Council currently performs this function very effectively for 
ADB  projects  in  the  North  East.  Consultants  funded  by  technical 
assistance  will  help  to  adopt  this  system  in  the  Southern  Provincial 
Council.

vi 
  The increased demand for tsunami rebuilding requires that each PMU 
be  strengthened  if  necessary,  particularly  in  accounting,  to 
accommodate the additional workload. Where a considerable amount of 
infrastructure work is needed, engineers will be added.  
   
Procurement  Procurement under both projects will be carried out in accordance with 
ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Procurement,  and  the  Government’s  tender 
procedures acceptable to ADB. For civil works contracts with estimated 
values greater than $5 million, procurement will be in accordance with 
international  competitive  bidding  procedures.  For  contracts  with 
estimated  values  of  $5 million  and  below,  procurement  will  be  in 
accordance  with  local  competitive  bidding  procedures  acceptable  to 
ADB, using single-stage, two-envelope procedures where relevant, and 
bidding periods of at least 21 days. For tsunami-related procurement, 
local competitive bidding periods can be reduced to 15 days.  
 
  Equipment  and  materials  will  be  procured  through  international 
competitive bidding when the estimated cost is more than $500,000 
equivalent, through international shopping when the estimated cost is 
between  $300,000  and  $500,000  equivalent,  and  through  local 
procurement procedures acceptable to ADB when the estimated cost is 
$300,000  equivalent  or  less.  Items  costing  less  than  $100,000 
equivalent may be directly purchased.  
 
  Most of the investments to be supported by TAARP are expected to 
come from within Sri Lanka or to involve some procurement from ADB 
member countries. However, to facilitate the European Commission’s 
cofinance  of  €40  million  proposed  under  the  road  rehabilitation  and 
reconstruction component, Board approval is now being sought to allow 
procurement in, and procurement of eligible goods and services from, 
member countries of the European Union, including ADB non-member 
countries. This would facilitate maximum and expeditious development 
and  catalyze  additional  resources  from  development  partners  in  the 
current post-tsunami emergency circumstance.

vii
Consulting  The  Government  has  requested  that  consultants  for  tsunami-related 
Services  services be engaged by ADB, in consultation with the Government, and 
in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and 
other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of 
international  and  domestic  consultants.  Consultants  for  the  road 
rehabilitation and rebuilding component will be selected from existing 
consultant design firms already engaged in ongoing road sector projects 
in Sri Lanka, subject to satisfactory performance, based on bio-data 
proposals and using the quality and cost based method of selection. 
Consulting design services required for all remaining tsunami-related 
components will be engaged through direct selection, typically through 
an extension of an existing contract. The consultants for NECORD who 
are currently providing procurement and contract management support 
and  training  of  domestic  agencies  will  extend  their  services  through 
direct selection to cover the additional requirements of the NECORD-
Tsunami and NECORD-II components. Consultants to be placed within 
PMUs will be hired as individuals. TAARP will require approximately 115 
person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and  881  person-
months  of  domestic  consulting  services.  NECORD-II  will  require 
approximately 200 person-months of domestic consulting services.

Project Benefits  The vast majority of those directly affected by the tsunami were at the 
and Beneficiaries  lower end of the economic scale, partly because the districts affected 
tended to have high levels of poverty at the time of the disaster and 
partly because people who lived in substandard housing were less able 
to resist the onslaught of the waves.  
 
In the conflict-affected North East, poverty levels are estimated to be 
60%–90%, much higher than in the rest of the country, although there 
are gaps in government surveys for much of the area.  
 
  Together, the two projects will address urgent needs of approximately 
3 million people, among whom the physically disabled, single heads-of-
households, and children feature significantly. By restoring sectors that 
form the backbone of the economy in affected areas, the projects will 
help to rebuild communities and stabilize the economic base of the local 
populations, helping them to move from dependency on government 
support towards sustainable livelihoods.  
 
Proactive  HIV/AIDS  awareness  programs  in  NECORD-II  will  be 
undertaken in the rapidly-expanding construction industry in the North 
East.  Programs  in  NECORD-II  will  also  support  gender  enterprise 
initiatives in the North East to address the needs of the many conflict 
widows, reduce their dependency on government support, and secure 
sustainable livelihoods for them.

viii 
Assumptions,  The  designs  of  TAARP  and  NECORD-II  incorporate  safeguards  to 
Risks and  improve and strengthen governance and the institutional capacity of the 
Mitigants  executing agencies, the implementing agencies, and the PMUs.  
 
A possible increase in social tensions and conflict among the major 
ethnic groups in the tsunami- and conflict-affected areas is a major risk. 
Such an increase in tensions and violence could come about as a result 
of  unbalanced  targeting,  and  undermining  implementation  of 
reconstruction.  TAARP  and  NECORD-II  have  been  designed  to 
minimize  this  risk  and will  be  implemented  so  that  balances  among 
ethnic groups and regions within all the affected areas are carefully 
monitored and managed. There will be transparency and community 
ownership  of  project  activities.  Both  projects  can  potentially  make  a 
positive contribution to rebuilding key infrastructure and make existing 
infrastructure more effective in strengthening the socioeconomic fabric of 
the tsunami- and conflict-affected areas.  
 
  In responding to the tsunami, Sri Lanka’s financial and human capacities 
are being strained. The volume and scale of tsunami-related foreign 
assistance being provided to Sri Lanka could lead to governance and 
corruption problems and weaknesses in the administration of justice. 
The size of public and private contributions to Sri Lanka may exceed the 
current capacity of the Government’s public administration to manage 
the  funds.  To  address  this  risk,  the  Government’s  capacity  for 
procurement,  financial  management,  environmental  assessment,  and 
resettlement, supervision and monitoring has been assessed and will be 
further enhanced through TAARP. Other factors designed to mitigate 
governance  and  corruption  risks  include:  legal  assistance,  detailed 
subproject selection criteria, transparent implementation and monitoring 
mechanisms, specific financial controls, and regular and random audits. 
ADB’s Sri Lanka Resident Mission is also strengthening its capacity to 
supervise and provide guidance and training to PMUs. A decentralized 
system of dispute resolution and grievance review will be established or 
strengthened  under  TAARP  to  investigate  and  resolve  any  private 
disputes  or  claims  of  impropriety  against  public  officials  relating  to 
tsunami  assistance.  The  public  will  be  provided  with  information  to 
ensure that tsunami-assistance funds are used for intended beneficiaries 
and  purposes  by  publishing  such  information  on  a  web-site  and  in 
Sinhala, Tamil and English in government newspapers. 
 
  Finally, reflecting the links between assistance in the North East and 
progress in the peace process, there is a risk that, if the peace process 
falters, NECORD-II’s scope and schedule may need to be reviewed. 
Despite  recent  political  and  other  uncertainties,  however,  the 
commitment to peace remains robust, the peace process remains intact, 
and the cease-fire agreed to in 2002 continues to be observed—this risk 
is therefore assessed to be small.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan from ADB’s Special Funds resources, and (ii) a proposed grant from the Asian Tsunami 
Fund  to  the  Democratic  Socialist  Republic  of  Sri  Lanka  for  the  Tsunami-affected  Areas 
Rebuilding Project, and (iii) a proposed loan from ADB’s Special Funds resources, and (iv) a 
grant from the Asian Development Fund to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for 
the North East Community Restoration and Development Project II. A design and monitoring 
framework is presented in Appendix 1a and 1b, respectively, for each proposed project.  
 
 
II.  RATIONALE: ANALYSIS, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Tsunami Impact and Needs Assessment 
 
2.  In the morning of Sunday 26 December 2004, a 9.0-magnitude earthquake off Sumatra 
sent several tsunami waves radiating out into the Bay of Bengal, the Andaman Sea, and the 
Indian  Ocean.  These  waves  struck  over  two  thirds  of  Sri  Lanka’s  coastline1  and  caused 
catastrophic destruction and considerable loss of life (see map).  
 
3.  As of February 2005, official figures indicated that over 31,000 people in Sri Lanka lost 
their lives in the tsunami, thousands more remain missing, and over 440,000 were displaced. 
The tsunami-affected population is between 1 and 2 million people, out of a total population of 
about 19 million.  
 
4.  In the wake of the disaster, the Government, as part of its reconstruction plan to address 
tsunami damage, launched a needs assessment and, within days, prepared an inventory of 
damage and losses. Three task forces were assembled to address the disaster, with the Task 
Force for Rebuilding the Nation (TAFREN), assigned to address reconstruction needs. At a 
meeting in late December 2004, ADB, the World Bank, and the Japan Bank for International 
Cooperation (JBIC), in coordination with the United Nations (UN), assisted the Government to 
develop  a  coastal  area  reconstruction  needs  assessment  to  serve  as  a  platform  for  all 
development partners interested in contributing to this effort.  
 
5.  The first phase of the needs assessment, conducted with technical assistance from 
ADB,2 began in early January 2005. The damage caused by the tsunami was surveyed and 
estimates of the financing requirements for post-tsunami construction were refined. Weekly 
meetings were held by multilateral and bilateral agencies, UN organizations, nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs), and civil society. A preliminary report was presented on 28 January 2005 
(Appendix 2 contains a summary of the needs assessment findings).  
 
6.  Tsunami-related  financing  needs  for  national  rebuilding  are  estimated  to  be  over 
$1.5 billion, in addition to the $200 million-$300 million that the Government estimates it has 
already spent, and excluding further relief expenditures. The fiscal impact of the tsunami will be 
more long term, given that estimated rebuilding costs will be the equivalent of almost 7% of 
annual gross domestic product.

7.  The  Government  estimates  that  nearly  100,000 houses  were  destroyed  during  the 
tsunami and another 46,000 were damaged. Nearly 170 public schools, 4 universities, and 18 
vocational and training centers were affected. The health sector suffered not only from damage 
to health-related infrastructure, but also through loss of services and human resources. Coastal 
courts  and  labor  tribunals,  prisons,  and  police  stations,  and  district  offices  that  contained 
personal and property documents were partially or completely destroyed.  
 
8.  About 1,400 kms of the national and provincial road network, and another 1,100 kms of 
local and village access roads were damaged. Bridges and culverts were also destroyed or 
displaced and embankments were eroded by the advancing and retreating tsunami. Flooding 
before and after the tsunami along the east coast further damaged the road network. The 
tsunami destroyed several sections of coastal railway lines, in particular on the Southern Line 
between Colombo and Galle along the Southwest coast. Water supply schemes and distribution 
networks along the shoreline were impacted, along with at least 12,000 water wells damaged 
mainly by saltwater intrusion; about 50,000 others were abandoned. Salinity contamination of 
stand crops in paddy and other crop fields or home gardens will limit or inhibit crop production 
for the next 3 to 4 years, until salinity is naturally flushed away through rain.  
 
9.  The damaged sustained to coastal livelihoods ranges from destroyed fishing boats to 
damaged informal guesthouses, through the loss of business inventories to the loss of simple 
tools and workshops. About 65% of the nation’s sea fishing boat fleet was either damaged or 
destroyed. About 3,500 hotel rooms out of about 14,000 rooms in medium to large-scale hotels 
are not in operation. In the small guesthouses, about 1,200 rooms out of a total 4,000 have 
been affected.  
 
10.  The second phase of the tsunami needs assessment process started in February 2005 
under the supervision of a steering committee made up of many stakeholders.3 The main 
objectives of phase II are: (i) to finalize the damage assessment figures by consulting with 
TAFREN and other stakeholders and to arrive at a consensus on reconstruction needs and 
financing requirements; and (ii) to develop implementation strategies for responding equitably to 
the needs of the tsunami-affected communities that will guide all parties engaged in post-
tsunami  reconstruction.  The  second  phase  will  involve  a  thorough  consultative  process 
conducted in districts by multisectoral teams drawn from TAFREN, the donor community, civil 
society, the private sector, and other stakeholders. These strategies will be completed by mid-
April 2005.  
 
B.  Conflict Impact and Needs Assessment 
 
11.  The coastal areas of the Northern and Eastern provinces had only recently begun to 
emerge  from  the  devastating  effects  of  the  nearly  20-year  civil  conflict  between  the 
Government’s armed forces and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) when the tsunami 
hit. The lengthy civil conflict left over 65,000 dead, several times as many people disabled, and 
nearly 800,000 people displaced from their homes. In February 2002, the Government and the 
LTTE signed a cease-fire agreement, thereby beginning a period of reconciliation, restoration, 
and reconstruction. However, a large percentage of people directly affected by the conflict still 
lack basic infrastructure and social services.

12.  In early 2003, multilateral agencies operating in Sri Lanka4 undertook a comprehensive 
assessment  of  reconstruction  needs  for  the  conflict-affected  areas,  primarily  in  the  eight 
districts5 that make up the North East (see map). The assessment, which was presented to the 
international community at the Sri Lanka Reconstruction and Development Conference held in 
Tokyo in June 2003,6 identified about $2 billion for immediate and medium-term needs, and 
$1 billion  for  longer-term  needs.  Of  this  $2  billion,  about  $780  million  was  identified  for 
immediate needs, and about $1.2 billion was identified for medium-term needs. To date, the 
international community has committed about $700 million––to address both immediate and 
medium-term needs. This leaves at least $80 million of the immediate needs unmet.  
 
C.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
13.  The tsunami needs assessment emphasized the importance of key guiding principles—
such as conflict sensitivity, subsidiarity, community empowerment, transparency, multi-hazard 
risk  management,  and  coordination  between  stakeholders—during  the  development  of  a 
comprehensive  recovery  strategy.  The  guiding  principles,  which  have  been  agreed  by  all 
concerned parties, are presented in Appendix 3. The international community has responded 
generously with pledges of tsunami assistance. However, if not approached and delivered 
sensitively, the provision of this tsunami assistance could risk exacerbating preexisting tensions, 
by creating a perception of unequal treatment of people affected by the conflict.  
 
14.  In addition to the problems and needs described above (paragraphs 6-9), the destruction 
wrought by the tsunami has generated legal issues for tsunami-affected people, including the 
loss of documents: titles to property; birth, death, and marriage certificates; identification cards; 
court  records;  and  bank  account  documents.  They  also  face  family,  custody,  adoption, 
inheritance, insurance, property rights and entitlement issues. The Department of the Registrar 
General (within the Ministry of Public Security, Law and Order) is attempting to reissue birth, 
death and marriage certificates, and the Department of the Registration of Persons (within the 
Ministry of Public Security, Law and Order), is attempting to issue identification cards to all 
tsunami-affected  persons.  To  the  extent  copies  of  documents  remain,  record-keeping  and 
retrieval  in  these  departments  is  currently  manually  done,  making  it  almost  impossible  to 
respond to some requests for replacement documents. Data collection from tsunami victims has 
not  been  coordinated  amongst  departments.  Additionally,  divisional  and  district  level 
government officials (district secretaries, divisional secretaries, and grama niladhari7) will need 
to  understand  the  new  legal  requirements,  and  document  processing  procedures  and  to 
proceed  along  appropriate  channels.  They  will  need  legal  assistance  to  resolve  any  legal 
questions that may arise. In the tsunami-affected areas, already poor and vulnerable people will 
have difficulty negotiating formal avenues, and clearly need assistance if they are to benefit 
from the new laws and procedures. In addition, the legal and factual issues generated by the 
tsunami are likely to lead to increased disputes and grievances, both among tsunami-affected 
people, and possibly against government officers and departments. The volume and scale of all 
tsunami-assistance provided to Sri Lanka could also lead to corruption. Current institutional 
structures may not be sufficient.

15.  The extent of debris, waste material, and rubble requiring disposal will lead to significant 
disposal  costs.  The  dumping  of  debris  in  inappropriate  locations  must  be  addressed 
immediately to prevent long-term problems of flood control, waterway blockages, contamination 
of the groundwater table, and pollution on beaches, for example by using debris as construction 
material when possible.  
 
16.  Because of Sri Lanka’s vulnerability to global warming, climate change, sea level rise, 
and extreme weather events, the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and other 
development partners are currently conducting environmental assessments of the devastation 
caused by the tsunami. Their objective is to identify follow-on projects and further studies in the 
likelihood of similar or localized natural disasters in the future, including the role of natural 
resources in minimizing the effect of natural disasters. As a result of the assessment by UNEP 
and its partners, tsunami reconstruction subprojects need to identify ways to (i) respond to the 
vulnerability of coastal populations to such disasters; (ii) prevent or reduce the magnitude of 
such  disasters;  (iii) educate  coastal  populations  on  disaster  preparedness  and  mitigation; 
(iv) improve  information  and  communication  systems;  and  (v) enhance  coastal  protection 
through natural barriers such as green zones or green belts of forests, coastal vegetation, or 
mangroves.  
 
17.  Both disasters have radically transformed gender roles. Women face the burden of 
caring and providing for the family, while contributing to community life in welfare centers or 
refugee camps. Conflict-related disability, often of males, has placed additional burdens on 
women and other family members. Family and household structures have been recast, with 
many families forming one household, households headed by one person (female and male), or 
families composed of grandparents and grandchildren. The conflict left many widows who took 
on the role of head of household, combining the traditional roles of breadwinner and caregiver. 
The tsunami has reversed this trend and left a large number of households headed by men. 
 
D.  Lessons Learned  
 
18.  ADB has considerable experience in implementing emergency reconstruction through its 
ongoing  projects  in  conflict-affected  areas.  These  projects  have  been  recognized  for  their 
(i) preparedness  to  respond  quickly  and  flexibly;  (ii) a  bottom-up  approach  to  subproject 
selection; (iii) balanced treatment of sectors, geographic areas, and ethnic groups; (iv) a focus 
on restoring facilities; (v) prompt supervision by ADB during implementation, as the projects 
place a heavy burden on executing and implementing agency staff; (vi) rapid action by the 
Government; and (vii) close donor coordination.  
 
19.  ADB’s experience has yielded the following lessons: (i) participation by all sections of 
affected  communities,  including  consultative  processes  and  social  mobilization,  needs 
assessments,  and  participatory  planning,  must  be  ensured  during  project  preparation  and 
implementation; (ii) the particular needs of women, households headed by one person, the 
elderly, and the disabled must be addressed; (iii) environmental and social aspects should be 
considered during project implementation, even though the need for rapid response may not 
permit detailed treatment of these issues before assistance is approved; (iv) arrangements for 
disbursements should give prompt and uncomplicated access to funds; (v) a focus on physical 
infrastructure alone reduces project benefits, so broader issues of assisting communities and 
affected areas to regain a productive life must be addressed; (vi) flexibility should be shown 
during implementation; (vii) there should be simple prioritization in subproject selection and 
short implementation periods, but there must also be a balanced distribution of benefits among 
communities  and  affected  areas;  (viii) close  and  frequent  monitoring  is  needed  to  ensure

5
transparency  and  facilitate  implementation;  and  (ix) the  large  number  of  Government  and 
externally-assisted rehabilitation programs in the affected areas must be properly coordinated at 
the local level. These lessons, learned in the conflict-affected areas, will be relevant to tsunami-
affected areas.  
 
E.  The Asian Development Bank’s Strategy  
 
20.  ADB’s disaster policy8 emphasizes a holistic and systematic approach to disaster and 
emergency assistance that extends beyond mere reconstruction to rehabilitation. It stresses 
strengthening or rebuilding institutions, developing appropriate policies, and training. Strategies 
for  short-term  rehabilitation  are  designed  to  lay  the  foundation  for  medium  and  long-term 
development. The disaster policy prioritizes strengthening of partnerships and efficient use of 
resources. In light of the need for an expeditious and transparent response, it also calls for 
extensive  participation  and  consultation,  and  measures  that  promote  transparency  and 
accountability, such as increased supervision and monitoring and special audits. It advocates 
emergency assistance loans to provide short-term assistance for efforts to rehabilitate priority 
infrastructure, revitalize social services, regenerate livelihoods, and provide transitional safety-
net support.9  
 
21.  In response to the special circumstances surrounding the developing member countries 
(DMCs) affected by the tsunami, ADB established an Asian Tsunami Fund (ATF)10 to channel 
resources from ADB and other donors to the affected DMCs. The ATF will channel emergency 
grant financing promptly and effectively to tsunami-related reconstruction and rehabilitation and 
associated development activities. The ATF will be used exclusively to restore services promptly 
to affected populations in the tsunami-affected DMCs that have requested ADB assistance: 
India, Indonesia, Maldives, Sri Lanka and Thailand. In a letter to ADB dated 17 February 2005, 
the Government of Sri Lanka requested grant assistance to address its reconstruction needs as 
a result of the tsunami disaster.  
 
22.  The country strategy and program update for Sri Lanka, 2005–2006,11 supports the 
Government's efforts to rehabilitate and reconstruct conflict-affected areas through the North 
East Community Restoration and Development Project II (NECORD-II). The Asian Development 
Fund IX (ADF IX) replenishment includes a new grant program that, inter alia, can be used to 
assist countries recovering from conflict as they make the transition to peace and stability. 
NECORD-II was programmed to receive ADF grant funding together with a loan for use in 
rehabilitation efforts in the conflict-affected North East.  
 
23.  The pre-tsunami conditions in the North East make it difficult to demarcate tsunami- and 
conflict-related  rebuilding  efforts.  ADB  assistance  for  post-tsunami  reconstruction  and 
NECORD-II will therefore be implemented simultaneously. This has been done to (i) apply the 
same  policies  and  standards  to  tsunami-  and  conflict-affected  people,  to  avoid  generating 
additional tensions or perceptions of unequal treatment; (ii) coordinate reconstruction activities; 
and (iii) link rehabilitation and reconstruction needs. The projects also provide a systematic 
approach to the conflict in the North East and the tsunami disaster by taking a decentralized 
approach and providing for rehabilitation of infrastructure, as well as coastal vulnerability, the 
risk of corruption and weak governance, gender, and social issues.

24.  At the request of the Government and to maintain clear accountability, two separate

F.  Donor Coordination 
 
25.  TAARP has been designed to be a part of a well-coordinated response to the disaster. 
The tsunami needs assessment carried out in January 2005, which is consistent with the needs 
assessment prepared by the Government and other studies developed for districts in the North 
East,12  was  used  to  determine  specific  interventions,  following  consultations  with  the 
Government  and  other  development  partners.  Given  the  many  expressions  of  interest  in 
supporting reconstruction in education, health, power, temporary shelter, risk management, and 
capacity building for future disasters, ADB has focused on roads, community infrastructure and 
shelter, restoring livelihoods, coastal protection, and governance. Within these sectors, ADB is 
coordinating with its partners; for example, in the area of livelihood restoration, the World Bank 
is supporting cash grants and “cash for work” programs in cooperation with the International 
Labour Organization, JBIC is providing a loan for the development of small and medium-sized 
enterprises, and ADB has extended a microfinance and microcredit facility. In addition, as a co-
chair of the needs assessment exercise, ADB has strongly promoted the adoption of common 
standards and policies that all external development partners should adopt in designing their 
interventions, in order to minimize potential for conflict and social tension. The role of the 
various partners in each sector is shown in Appendix 4.  
 
26.  Separate  assistance  grants  from  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  are  being 
processed to provide a total of $4 million to Sri Lanka to restore and create line drainage 
systems along tsunami-affected roads and to provide microfinance opportunity for post-tsunami 
utility connections at newly-built or repaired houses. Outreach programs will provide information 
to affected people on microfinance opportunities. These programs will be independent from, but 
complementary to, the projects described in this paper; separate Board approval will be sought 
for these assistance grants.  
 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TSUNAMI-AFFECTED AREAS REBUILDING PROJECT 
 
A.  Objective 
 
27.  The objective of the Tsunami-affected Areas Rebuilding Project (TAARP) is to rapidly 
improve the living conditions and well-being of a significant number of people in tsunami-
affected areas by restoring basic social infrastructure, community and public services, and 
livelihoods in these areas.  
 
B.  Components and Outputs 
 
28.  TAARP will address the needs of the tsunami-affected people through subprojects in a 
variety of sectors formulated in response to requests from tsunami-affected persons and the

and provide further environmental protection. All new construction will be in accordance with 
Government regulations and guidelines for tsunami reconstruction. A detailed breakdown of

overview of the subproject selection process is presented in Appendix 6. Governance, anti-

1.  Component A: Legal Assistance, Governance and Anticorruption  
 
29.  The destruction wrought by the tsunami has generated legal and documentary issues for 
tsunami-affected  people  and  the  Government,  and  the  generous  contributions  of  foreign 
assistance have raised potential governance and corruption issues for the government.  The 
Legal Assistance, Governance and Anticorruption Component seeks to address these issues. It 
will  provide  legal  assistance  to  tsunami-affected  victims  to  help  them  address  legal  and 
documentary issues arising from the tsunami. It will also establish a decentralized mechanism 
for tsunami victims for private dispute resolution and grievance review against public officials. 
Three proposals for achieving this end are currently under discussion with the government, and 
it is most likely to involve a combination of these mechanisms. They are establishing (a) tsunami 
mediation boards to address tsunami related disputes and grievances, based on existing and 
working statutory mediation boards; (b) a decentralized office of tsunami ombudsmen, or an 
extension of the work of the existing Ombudsmen to deal with grievances against public officials 
relating to the tsunami; and/or (c) establishing a unit within the administrative division of Sri 
Lanka’s Bribery and Corruption Commission, to concentrate on detecting, investigating, and 
otherwise responding to corruption in tsunami-assistance. In addition, training and awareness 
workshops will be conducted for judges, magistrates, district officials, and the public on the 
potential tsunami or disaster emergency related legal issues, disputes or cases that are likely to 
arise. This will include the tsunami legislative framework that is currently under consideration for 
making special provision for persons and property affected by the tsunami.  
 
30.  The  replacement  of  birth,  death,  and  marriage  certificates,  and  property  titles,  and 
identification  cards  will  be  supported.  Methods  used  for  replacing  documents  will  include 
supporting the collection and coordination of data by the relevant departments and offices, and 
through  modernizing  computer  collection  of  such  data;  transforming  manual  central  record 
keeping  at  the  Registrar  General’s  department  and  the  Department  of  the  Registration  of 
Persons into computerized record keeping, and facilitating the connectivity, coordination and 
networking of such information. This will facilitate location of records lost by tsunami victims, 
and hence the reissue of relevant certificates and cards. In the process of data collection, 
tsunami  victim  identity  cards  will  be  provided  so  as  to  reduce  the  extent  false  claims  for 
assistance can be made. TAARP will also support transparency of tsunami and emergency 
assistance, through the Office of the President by supporting the publication in Sinhala, Tamil, 
and English, on the internet and in government newspapers, of (i) modes of tsunami assistance 
from  development  partners  and  NGOs,  (ii)  contract  and  procurement  details  in  relation  to 
tsunami-assistance, (iii) any proposed laws, bills, or policy relating to tsunami assistance, and 
(iv) Sri Lanka’s assistance to tsunami-affected people.  
 
31. Finally, the MOFP will be assisted to ensure good governance in NGO provision of tsunami 
assistance by supporting the development of guidelines or regulations on NGO governance, 
accountability,  transparency,  and  registration  in  the  provision  of  tsunami  assistance.  An 
extensive description of these components is provided in Appendix 7.

8 
2.  Component B: North East Coastal Community Development 
 
32.  Coastal  communities  in  the  districts  of  Jaffna,  Mullaittivu,  Kilinochchi,  Trincomalee, 
Batticaloa  and  Ampara  that  were  affected  by  the  tsunami  will  receive  support  under  this 
component. Communities that have been affected by the tsunami in terms of loss of life, 
destruction of assets, and disruption of livelihoods will be identified for support. Communities—
i.e.,  Grama  Niladhari  divisions  (footnote 7)—that  meet  the  criteria  will  receive  support  for: 
(i) construction of small-scale community infrastructure; (ii) livelihood development activities; 
and  (iii) community  development  planning  and  coordination  at  the  local  authority  level.  In 
addition, this component will support restoration and sustainable management of natural habitat 
damaged during the tsunami and support coastal resource planning and management at district 
and provincial levels.  
 
33.  Infrastructure.  Small-scale  community  infrastructure  could  include  minor  roads, 
culverts,  drains,  small-scale  water  supply  and  sanitation  facilities,  simple  solid  waste 
management  schemes,  community  buildings  and  market  and/or  auction  halls.  Livelihood 
support interventions will consist of advisory services to identify and develop suitable livelihood 
options (including small enterprises), skills development, and transfer of technology. These 
advisory  services  will  be  linked  with  microcredit  provided  under  component  G.  All  these 
activities will need to be coordinated at the local authority level, so support for such coordination 
and planning will be provided under this component.  
 
34.  Coastal  Zone  Planning.  The  tsunami  highlighted  the  importance  of  coastal  zone 
planning in averting or at least reducing the impact of natural disasters. TAARP will support 
coastal zone planning that takes into account existing natural habitats and land use patterns. 
The planning process will be participatory, with coordination at division, district, and provincial 
levels, and eventual integration with the National Coastal Zone Management Plan.  
 
35.  Natural  Resources.  Restoration  of  degraded  or  destroyed  natural  habitats  will  be 
undertaken through a community-based process. TAARP will support restoration of such areas 
and concurrently develop livelihood or supplementary income generating activities that will 
benefit  adjacent  communities  and  thereby  ensure  sustainable  management  of  the  natural 
habitat.  
 
3.  Component C: Road Rehabilitation and Reconstruction 
 
36.  National  Roads.  Subprojects  will  rehabilitate,  reconstruct,  or  improve  road  links 
damaged by the tsunami and improve the transport network overall. Among other benefits, this 
will improve the response to disasters. Access along tsunami-affected coastal roads has been 
restored, albeit through temporary repairs. However, the road resurfacing and embankment 
restorations that have been carried out are not anticipated to last beyond the next monsoon 
season. Tsunami-affected roads will be rebuilt according to national standards for each class of 
road. Road works will include reconstruction of previously-surfaced roads and drainage, location 
and  removal  of  mines  and  unexploded  ordnance,  repair  or  replacement  of  bridges  as 
necessary, and a review of “black-spot” or accident-prone areas so safety improvements can be 
incorporated into civil works. Road works will be designed to improve roads and make them 
more resistant to expected coastal weather and drainage patterns. Road shoulders will be 
paved where possible to provide better access and safer conditions for cyclists and pedestrians. 
About 300 kilometers (km) of major coastal road links (class A and B) in tsunami-affected areas 
in the South and North East of Sri Lanka will be rebuilt.

9
37.  Subject to Board approval, and successful conclusion of a joint cofinancing agreement, 
ADB  will  administer  a  European  Commission  grant  to  rehabilitate  sections  of  the  Matara-
Batticaloa national road under TAARP. TAARP will both rebuild the roads after the tsunami and 
improve  connections  between  the  southern  and  eastern  road  networks.  This  will  facilitate 
delivery of supplies and promote economic development in conflict-affected areas.  
 
38.  Access Roads. The local government roads subcomponent will include rehabilitation of 
access  road  networks  and  bridges  damaged  by  the  tsunami  in  the  Galle,  Matara  and 
Hambantota districts. About 200 km of damaged class C, D, and E provincial roads in the 
Southern Province will be rebuilt and provided with improved drainage. Another 200 km of rural 
roads will be rebuilt in the coastal belt. Road safety improvements will be incorporated into 
designs  as  necessary.  Where  possible,  debris  will  be  recycled  for  use  as  road  sub-base 
material for construction.  
 
4.  Component D: Water Supply and Sanitation 
 
39.  Drinking water supply and sanitation schemes in Hambantota, Batticaloa and Muttur 
districts (which were affected by the tsunami) will be repaired and expanded. Subprojects will 
provide  for  additional  distribution  using  temporary  intakes  and  for  community-based  water 
supply together with individual sanitation facilities.  
 
5.  Component E: Southern Province Reconstruction 
 
40.  Infrastructure. Subprojects in component E will restore livelihoods by creating jobs for 
locally-based skilled and unskilled labor and reconstructing community and urban infrastructure, 
which could include local government roads, culverts, drains, small-scale water supply and 
sanitation  facilities,  simple  solid  waste  management  schemes,  village  markets  (polas), 
ayurvedic  (traditional  medicine)  dispensaries,  children’s  parks,  playgrounds,  community 
buildings and rest houses, market and/or auction halls. Training for new employment skills will 
be offered. Physical infrastructure and buildings, such as public libraries, courts, police stations, 
prisons,  and  district  registry  offices  needed  to  reestablish  an  effective  law  and  public 
administration  system  will  also  be  reconstructed.  Designs  for  reconstructed  buildings  will 
provide disabled access. Community-level subprojects will be selected and prioritized generally 
through the subproject selection process described in Appendix 6. TAARP will also support 
community development planning and coordination at the local authority level.  
 
41.  Shelter. Nearly 100,000 houses were destroyed by the tsunami. Other donors have 
made  significant  commitments  for  the  reconstruction  of  damaged  or  destroyed  housing  in 
tsunami-affected areas. However, if demands  remain unmet, this component will construct 
shelter  for  vulnerable  tsunami-affected  families  in  the  Southern  Province.  Shelter  will  be 
provided  in  situ—only  at  preexisting  house  sites—and  in  accordance  with  Government 
regulations  for  tsunami  reconstruction,  including  Government  policy  on  selection  and  total 
assistance  allowance  per  family.  If  adequate  donor  financing  is  available  for  shelter 
reconstruction,  funds  for  this  subcomponent  will  be  used  for  other  village  and  community 
infrastructure subprojects.  
 
6.  Component F: Coastal Resources Management 
 
42.  Subprojects  will  repair  damage  done  to  coastal  stabilization  structures  and  harbor 
breakwaters, extend such structures, identify additional sites for improvements, and provide 
small fishing boat anchorages and fisheries-related ancillary units, such as boat-building yards,

10 
net repair sheds, or cold-storage facilities, in the Southern and Western provinces. Subprojects 
will  also  provide  enhanced  coastal  protection  and  environmental  management  along  the 
affected coasts by reestablishing green zones or green belts through intensive forestation with 
coastal vegetation, including mangroves. These green zones or belts will be effective barriers 
against  coastal  erosion  and  other  potentially  life-threatening  events  such  as  cyclones, 
hurricanes, floods, tsunamis, and higher sea levels. Where practical, tsunami debris will be used 
as core fill material for construction of breakwaters and groins.  
 
7.  Component G: Rural Finance  
 
43.  Immediate support is needed so affected people can rebuild their lives and regain their 
dignity,  and  so  local  economies  can  be  revived.  This  component  will  include  (i) restoring 
livelihoods  of  affected  poor  households  or  groups  affected  by  the  tsunami  by  providing 
immediate  access  to  noncommercial  microcredit,  (ii) supporting  microenterprise  and  skills 
training, (iii) mitigating risk by insuring affected households or individuals that receive assistance 
under this component through life and property insurance schemes, and (iv) providing support 
for operational costs and rebuilding of physical assets of microfinance institutions in remote 
areas.  
 
44.  A  major  change  in  implementation  arrangements  for  the  Rural  Finance  Sector 
Development Program13 (RFSDP) was approved by ADB Vice President (Operations Group 1) 
on 23 February 2005 to provide microcredit will be provided to certain classes of tsunami 
affected people. TAARP will provide microcredit on similar but broader terms to the revised 
arrangements to the tsunami-affected people who need them most—low-income households, 
which  comprise  about  75%  of  all  affected  households.  The  interest  rate  charged  will  be 
noncommercial and in line with the Central Bank of Sri Lanka directive for loans to tsunami-
affected persons. These loans, together with rescheduling of existing debts, will enable more 
money  to  be  spent  on  household  needs.  Loans  to  affected  households  will  be  limited  to 
Rs100,000 (approximately $1,000) to ensure a focus on poor households. The grant portion of 
this component will be used to finance items (ii) to (v) above and detailed during inception.  
 
8.  Component H: NECORD—Tsunami 
 
45.  Some of the basic and social infrastructure works already replaced or rehabilitated in the 
North East coastal areas under NECORD were destroyed by the tsunami. Subprojects will 
redesign and rebuild structures in the health, education, water supply and sanitation, irrigation, 
rural roads, village and community development infrastructure, and fishing sectors. Shelter and 
institutional infrastructure, including courts and district registries, with improved access for the 
disabled, will be provided at preexisting sites. Designs will incorporate risk-mitigating measures 
to improve durability and avert or reduce the impact of natural disasters.  
 
C.  Special Features 
 
46.  TAARP will address urgent basic needs and social services lost as a result of the 
tsunami. If life in the affected and neighboring areas is to return to normal, social services must 
be restored, destroyed infrastructure must be rebuilt, and access to employment opportunities 
must be made available. TAARP has therefore been processed under ADB’s disaster policy.

Since  interventions  will  typically  replace  preexisting  assets—reconstructed  to  appropriate 
contemporary standards—economic analysis is not required.14 Investments will be made on the 
basis  of  least-cost  restoration  of  preexisting  facilities.  The  procedures  for  project  loan 
processing, procurement, consultant engagement, subproject selection, and the type of works to 
be done reflect this flexibility, without sacrificing quality, transparency, or safeguards. However, 
efforts  will  be  made  to  provide  proper  targeting,  subproject  control  and  monitoring,  and 
community participation and to address area resource and capacity constraints.  
 
47.  ADB will focus on ensuring project implementation is efficient, effective, and expedient. 
Following the disaster policy, additional resources have been dedicated to implementation, 
supervision and monitoring, including (i) support for the National Procurement Agency, (ii) 
provision of resettlement specialists and external monitors for unanticipated resettlement and 
land acquisition, (iii) an environment specialist to assist environmental assessment of tsunami-
related  projects  by  the  Government's  Central  Environmental  Authority,  (iv)  additional 
accountants, (v) private sector financial auditors, and (vi) performance auditors.  
 
48.  The  volume  and  scale  of  foreign  assistance  to  Sri  Lanka  will  generate  a  risk  of 
corruption. The Government is committed to a zero-tolerance policy against corruption, and to 
ensuring  that  vulnerable  tsunami-affected  people  are  adequately  protected.  TAARP 
incorporates features specifically designed to address these risks. It provides for enhanced 
supervision and monitoring, regular financial and random performance audits, and measures to 
increase transparency of tsunami assistance and policy, through publication of tsunami-related 
assistance and information in all three languages, in government newspapers and the internet. 
It requires participation and consultation with local government, and civil society stakeholders, 
starting with the planning and policy-setting stage. District-level consultations will be held to 
complete the needs assessment that will provide the framework for reconstruction activity. It will 
also establishes decentralized mechanism(s) for ensuring public accountability, and addressing 
private grievances either by tsunami ombudsmen, tsunami mediation boards, or establishing a 
tsunami  unit  within  the  administrative  division  of  Sri  Lanka’s  Bribery  and  Corruption 
Commission.  In  addition,  by  establishing  decentralized  provision  of  legal  assistance  and 
facilitation, TAARP provides a means of legal empowerment and allows vulnerable and poor 
tsunami-affected people to access formal and informal channels of accountability and grievance 
review. Finally, the issuance and reissuance of identification cards, computer automation of 
manual  record  keeping  systems,  and  improved  and  networked  coordination  amongst 
departments accessing data will limit the extent that persons can abuse systems for tsunami 
assistance. These features are described in detail in Appendix 8.

F.  Justification for Special Loan Terms and Grants  
 
1.  ADB Loan  
 
57.  Sri Lanka is a tsunami-affected country beginning rehabilitation and reconstruction. It is 
also recovering from conflict and making the transition to peace and stability. The disaster policy 
modifies the prevailing ADF lending terms approved by the ADB Board so they are appropriate 
for disaster, emergency, and post-conflict assistance.21 ADB has approved the use of such 
terms in Bangladesh for the Emergency Flood Damage Rehabilitation Project (January 2005), in 
Sri Lanka for the North East Community Restoration and Development – Extension Project22 
and in the Maldives Tsunami Emergency Assistance Project (the Approved Loans). The loan 
from the portfolio reallocation from the ADF would be made on concessional terms permitted 
under ADB's Disaster Policy and the same as those of the Approved Loans. The term of the 
loan will be 40 years, including a grace period of 10 years, with a repayment of principal at 2% 
per year for the first 10 years after the grace period and 4% a year thereafter, to be paid 
semiannually, with an interest charge at the rate of 1% per annum.  
 
2.  ATF Grant 
 
58.  Sri  Lanka  is  eligible  to  receive  tsunami  grant  funds  in  accordance  with  the  terms 
approved by the Board under the Asian Tsunami Fund.23

2.  Selection and Approval of Subprojects 
 
70.  Subprojects will be selected to ensure rehabilitation activities are distributed equitably 
across all the tsunami-affected districts—taking into account geographic and sector balances as 
well as the ethnic composition of the areas. Subprojects will be selected in accordance with 
sector-specific criteria agreed upon by the Government and ADB (Appendix 5a). In addition, 
regardless of the sector, each subproject proposal will be evaluated on the basis of general 
criteria, as set forth below.  
 
(i)  The subproject will rehabilitate or reconstruct tsunami-damaged infrastructure, 
and/or directly address the requirements of tsunami-affected people. 
 
(ii)  The subproject will be identified and prioritized based on the tsunami needs 
assessment  for  the  area  and  will  take  into  account  consultations  with 
beneficiaries and affected people. 
(iii)  The subproject will reflect the requirement that there should be a reasonable 
balance of activities among communities and districts. 
 
(iv)  The subproject will not be financed by ADB if it is being financed by another 
development  partner,  unless  the  other  development  partner  and  ADB  are 
cofinancing it, and where practical, preference will be given to other development 
partners that express interest in financing the subproject. 
 
(v)  The  subproject  will  be  technically  feasible,  financially  sustainable,  and  will 
represent the least-cost alternative, taking into account the need to provide for a 
reasonable increase in demand in the future;  
 
(vi)  The equipment, materials, and other resources required can be acquired in, or 
transported to, the subproject location without unreasonable obstruction or delay. 
 
(vii)  The subproject can be completed within the remaining implementation period; 
 
(viii)  The subproject will not use asbestos in construction or as a construction material.  
 
(ix)  The  subproject  will  be  in  compliance  with  the  Government's  environmental 
requirements,  ADB's  Environment  Policy34  (2002),  and  the  Environmental 
Assessment  and  Review  Framework.  For  subprojects  that  require  an  initial 
environmental  examination  (IEE),  the  IEE  will  be  included  in  the  subproject 
proposal, and government environmental clearance will have been obtained prior 
to the award of the subproject contract. The subproject is not a Category A 
subproject. 
 
(x)  The  subproject  will  not,  to  the  extent  possible,  require  land  acquisition  or 
involuntary resettlement. If either of these is, in fact, required in the course of 
TAARP, it will be conducted in conformity with the Government’s applicable law 
and policy, ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy 35 (1995), and the resettlement 
framework.

3.  Implementation Period 
 
71.  Although  project  administration  systems  for  each  component  are  already  fully 
functioning, and subproject implementation can therefore commence quickly, the geographic 
distribution  and  extent  of  damage  caused  by  the  tsunami  necessitate  that  TAARP  be 
implemented over a 4-year period. This will provide time to design and package civil works 
contracts—particularly for road rebuilding—and for adequate consultation and development of 
various village and community subprojects. The scheduled completion date is 30 June 2009 
(Appendix 11).  
 
4.  Social and Environmental Measures 
 
72.  TAARP is not expected to require land acquisition or resettlement; only vacant state-
owned land is expected to be used for subproject improvements. Rehabilitation and rebuilding 
will typically take place only at existing infrastructure locations. The works will be designed to 
ensure that improvements will be within existing property boundaries. However, a summary 
resettlement framework (Appendix 12) has been agreed upon by the Government and ADB.  
While  no  resettlement  is  anticipated,  the  agreed  Resettlement  Framework  sets  out  the 
compensation and other entitlements for any unanticipated land acquisition and/or resettlement. 
In addition, the Financing Agreements contain detailed covenants that require the Government 
to comply with ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). The policy and legal framework 
for  Government  post-tsunami  assistance  is  being  developed,  with  new  guidelines  recently 
adopted, and new laws under consideration.36 While a Resettlement Framework is usually 
finalized by Board approval, the agreed Resettlement Framework for TAARP may be refined by 
ADB in consultation with the Government prior to any land acquisition and/or resettlement under

Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995), as would be allowed under the disaster policy.37

5.  Procurement of Civil Works and Equipment

ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement and the Government’s tender procedures acceptable to 
ADB.  ADB’s  disaster  policy  permits  flexible  interpretation  of  these  guidelines,  so  project 
activities can start promptly. ADB has also been advising the National Procurement Agency on

without sacrificing transparency and competition. Consultant support will be provided through

be  in  accordance  with  international  competitive  bidding  procedures.  For  contracts  with 
estimated  values  of  $5 million  and  below,  procurement  will  be  in  accordance  with  local

procurement, local competitive bidding periods can be reduced from 21 to 15 days.

the estimated cost is more than $500,000 equivalent, by international shopping where the

80.  As described above in para. 55, the European Commission is prepared to commit to

IV.  THE PROPOSED NORTH EAST COMMUNITY RESTORATION  
AND DEVELOPMENT PROJECT II 
 
A.  Objective 
 
95.  The main objective of NECORD-II is rapidly to improve the living conditions and well-
being of a significant number of people in conflict-affected areas by restoring basic social 
infrastructure, community and public services, and livelihoods. NECORD-II will also support and 
augment Sri Lanka’s rehabilitation and relief efforts underway in the conflict-affected North East.  
 
                                                 
40  Para. 108 of the Disaster and Emergency Assistance Policy.

26 
B.  Components and Outputs 
 
96.  Rehabilitation  subprojects  will  address  (i) community  development,  (ii) civil  works –
 access/rural roads, (iii) institutional infrastructure and institutional strengthening, and (iv) civil 
works – basic infrastructure. Subprojects will be selected and prioritized generally through the 
subproject selection process described in Appendix 6.  
 
1.  Community Development 
 
97.  Village Development. A wide range of village-level subprojects across several sectors 
will restore livelihoods, provide opportunities for income generation, and support reconciliation 
and social cohesion. Livelihood opportunities will be provided in the agricultural sector through 
subprojects that promote livestock development and market gardening, and provide facilities for 
seed  production.  District  agriculture  centers  will  be  restored  to  assist  farmers.  Skills 
development and training will be provided for micro-enterprise development in areas such as 
horticulture, food processing, and tourism. To enable community-based organizations (CBOs) to 
promote micro-enterprises at the village level, revolving funds will be established and managed 
by  CBOs.  Gender-oriented  enterprise  programs,  initiated  as  a  pilot  program  under  the 
NECORD – Extension  Project,  will  be  expanded  to  cover  a  wider  range  of  coastal  and 
agricultural communities. Given the influx of construction workers, an HIV/AIDS awareness 
campaign  will  be  carried  out  among  construction  workers  and  internally  displaced  people. 
NECORD-II will also promote the advancement of women at women’s industrial centers, an 
initiative begun under the NECORD – Extension Project.  
 
98.  Shelter. Conflict-affected returnees will be provided shelter at their previous house sites. 
Shelter reconstruction will follow Government policy in the selection of families and the total 
assistance allowance per family.  
 
2.  Civil Works—Access Roads  
 
99.  Access road construction will use labor-intensive methods to provide gravel-surfaced 
rural roads, connecting villages to the road network, irrigation schemes, or community facilities. 
A small number of class C or D provincial roads will be rehabilitated with all-weather surfaces. 
All  road  construction  will  be  on  existing  alignments  and  is  not  expected  to  require  land 
acquisition or resettlement.  
 
3.  Institutional Infrastructure  
 
100.  Infrastructure and Institutional Strengthening. Institutional capacity will be improved 
through subprojects that restore or reestablish damaged local government facilities and district 
offices, and rehabilitate courts and registrars’ offices in the North East. Designs for replacement 
facilities will provide disabled access. NECORD-II will also supply training to staff on public 
administration, accounts, and information management. In anticipation of the growing need for 
skilled  employees,  training  will  be  given  to  youths  in  construction,  motor  mechanics,  and 
tourism-related trades, and will encompass construction of any special facilities required to 
provide these trainings.  
 
4.  Civil Works—Basic Infrastructure 
 
101.  Health.  Subprojects  will  restore  critical  referral  medical  facilities  through  hospital 
reconstruction  and  refurbishment,  provision  and  replacement  of  medical  equipment  and

27
furniture, construction of doctor’s quarters at hospital compounds, and rehabilitation of village 
health clinics.  
 
102.  Education.  Subprojects  will  restore  services  and  facilities  by  (i) reconstructing  and 
rehabilitating teaching facilities and school buildings; (ii) constructing cluster housing units for 
teachers on unencumbered lands, in areas where existing housing is limited or unavailable; and 
(iii) providing teacher training in primary education, English, science and math. Training will be 
provided to improve the quality of the teachers, especially new recruits.  
 
103.  Water Supply and Sanitation. Improvements will be made to the water supply and 
sanitation facilities in small and medium-sized towns. These will be linked to village community 
development activities, particularly where internally displaced persons (IDPs) are returning.  
 
104.  Irrigation.  Existing  medium-sized  and  large  irrigation  schemes  will  be  rehabilitated 
through restoration of tank bunds, channel systems, access roads, and other structures, without 
changes to, or diversions of, natural watercourses. The activity will be linked to the village, 
agriculture and livestock development.  
 
105.  Land mine and unexploded ordnance (UXO) contamination of proposed subproject sites 
in the North East is not expected to be substantial, even after the effects of the tsunami. 
Although there are a significant number of landmines and UXO still uncleared in the North 
East—contaminated areas were well defined prior to the tsunami—most coastal areas, being 
densely populated, had already been priorities for mine and UXO clearance. In these areas, 
there were few mines left. Areas around military installations on the coast, where mines were 
concentrated, may have been affected by the tsunami, but dealing with these is relatively 
straightforward, as the number of affected areas is small. Clearance in the tsunami-affected 
areas is currently being done by agencies already involved in mine clearance (e.g., the Sri 
Lankan Army and the HALO Trust) and has almost been completed. However, as a further 
safeguard, provisions for obtaining clearance certification of subproject sites in the North East 
will be incorporated into each civil works contract.  
 
C.  Special Features 
 
106.  NECORD-II has been formulated to address urgent basic needs and social services lost 
as a result of the 20-year conflict and is therefore, like TAARP, being processed under the 
disaster policy. NECORD-II will be implemented expeditiously, but extra effort and time will be 
taken  to  provide  proper  targeting  and  adequate  subproject  control  and  monitoring,  ensure 
community  participation,  and  address  area  resource  capacity  constraints.  NECORD-II 
interventions  will  generally  replace  preexisting  assets,  reconstructed  to  appropriate 
contemporary standards. Economic analysis is not required, but investments will be made on 
the basis of least-cost restoration of pre-existing facilities.  
 
107.  NECORD-II  takes  a  proactive  stance  towards  the  risks  of  increased  HIV/AIDS41 
transmission  by  providing  an  awareness  training  program.  Given  the  recent  increase  in

F.  Justification for Special Loan Terms and Grants 
 
1.  ADF Loan  
 
114.  Sri Lanka is recovering from conflict and making the transition to peace and stability. 
ADB's disaster policy modifies the prevailing ADF lending terms approved by the ADB Board so 
they are appropriate for disaster, emergency, and post-conflict assistance. The disaster policy 
covers post-conflict assistance and provides that emergency assistance loans are to cover 
short-term  immediate  needs  including  rehabilitation  of  priority  water,  transport,  and  other 
infrastructure, to regenerate livelihoods and boost productivity, and revitalize social services, 
among other things (footnote 9). The ADF loan would be extended to Sri Lanka to cover a 
portion of the remaining unfunded immediate term needs identified in the 2003 post-conflict 
needs assessment and still unmet (refer to paragraph 12 for the description of these needs), 
including  rehabilitation  of  priority  infrastructure,  regeneration  of  livelihoods,  boosting

30 
productivity, and revitalizing social services. It is proposed that the loan from ADF be made on 
concessional terms permitted under ADB's disaster policy, and the same as the Approved 
Loans. The term of the loan will be 40 years, including a grace period of 10 years, with a 
repayment of principal at 2% per year for the first 10 years after the grace period and 4% a year 
thereafter, to be paid semiannually, with an interest charge at the rate of 1% per annum.  
 
2.  ADF Grant 
 
115.  The Board of Governors of ADB resolved to establish a new grant program during the 
Asian Development Fund IX Annual Meeting, under the ADF IX resolution42. Donors agreed that 
ADF grants could be used to assist poor countries make the transition from post-conflict to 
peace and stability, as well as for HIV/AIDS prevention. Sri Lanka was identified as one of the 
post-conflict countries and eligible for ADF grants43. The post-conflict situation in the North East 
of  Sri  Lanka  qualifies  Sri  Lanka  for  such  ADF  grant  funding.  In  addition,  the  HIV/AIDS 
subcomponent qualifies for ADF grant financing, although, as it is not a large subcomponent, 
will be financed through the post-conflict country allocation of the ADF grant.  
 
G.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
1.  Project Management 
 
116.  NECORD-II will be implemented using the same process approach and implementation 
arrangements  as  NECORD  that  are  already  working  successfully.  NECORD’s  PMU  in 
Trincomalee will be strengthened and maintained for the duration of NECORD-II. The PMU will 
be headed by the project director, who will have direct responsibility for implementing NECORD-
II, through the existing provincial and central government sector agencies, and for ensuring that 
the  essential  balances  among  communities  are  monitored  and  maintained.  The  PMU  will 
manage and coordinate subprojects through existing structures and procedures at provincial, 
district, and division levels. The PMU will act as the secretariat for NPCC and PPCC. The PMU 
may engage suitably qualified and acceptable international and domestic NGOs to manage 
specific NECORD-II activities in accordance with procedures acceptable to ADB. District project 
management units (DPMUs) established in each district under NECORD will continue to closely 
monitor the implementation of district subprojects and report to the PMU. A deputy project 
director,  who  will  directly  implement  smaller-scale subprojects  at  the  district  and  divisional 
levels, will head each DPMU. 
 
117.  Given the complexity and sensitivity of NECORD-II and the need for close coordination 
with the actors in the North East—the Government, LTTE, external assistance agencies, NGOs, 
and others—NECORD-II will be administered through the ADB Resident Mission in Colombo.  
 
2.  Selection and Approval of Subprojects 
 
118.  Subprojects will be selected to ensure equitable distribution of rehabilitation activities 
across all the conflict-affected districts—taking into account geographic and sector balances 
along with the ethnic composition—to maximize benefits in the affected areas and, equally 
important, to not contribute to the intercommunal tensions that led to the conflict. NECORD-II

upon by the Government and ADB, as presented in Appendix 5b. In addition, regardless of the

3.  Implementation Period 
 
119.  Like  TAARP,  NECORD-II  will  be  implemented  over  a  4-year  period.  This  period  is 
needed because of the geographic distribution and extent of damage caused by the 20-year 
conflict, the time required to formulate and package subprojects and civil works contracts, the 
necessity for community consultation and mobilization, the potential need for clearance of mines 
and unexploded ordnance, and the limitations of still evolving institutions. Capacity building at 
the various implementing departments and the construction industry in the North East has 
begun—in part through the NECORD subprojects already completed—but the need for further 
capacity building remains. Contractor capacity has been strengthened in the North East through 
a series of construction and contracting seminars presented in 2004 by Deutsche Gesellschaft 
für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ) and  ADB.  Equally important, the conflict destroyed 
much of the human capacity in the area, in the Government, NGOs, and the private sector. 
NECORD-II will continue the essential but time- and resource-consuming task of rebuilding this 
capacity.  The  existing  national  project  coordinating  committee  and  provincial  project 
coordinating committee will continue to operate under NECORD-II. The scheduled completion 
date is 30 June 2009, the same as for TAARP (Appendix 11).  
 
4.  Social and Environmental Measures 
 
120.  Like TAARP, NECORD-II is not expected to require land acquisition or resettlement; only 
vacant  state-owned  land  will  be  used  for  subproject  improvements.  Reconstruction  and 
rehabilitation will typically take place at existing locations. Works will be designed to ensure that 
improvements will be within existing property boundaries. If constructed, cluster-housing units 
for teachers will be located only at or adjacent to existing education facilities, on unencumbered 
government land. A summary resettlement framework as presented in Appendix 12, has been 
agreed upon by the Government and ADB to address any unanticipated land acquisition or 
involuntary resettlement that may arise during NECORD-II. Refer to paragraph 72 above. 
 
121.  Like TAARP (para. 73), NECORD-II will focus on rehabilitation and reconstruction of 
preexisting  infrastructure  damaged  as  a  result  of  the  conflict,  and  is  also  classified  as 
environmental category B. No subprojects classified as category A by ADB will be financed 
under  NECORD-II.  A  summary  IEE  is  presented  in  Appendix 13.  Subprojects  will  follow 
environmental assessment procedures stipulated in the environmental assessment framework 
attached as Appendix 14. While NECORD-II may lead to temporary and reversible localized 
negative  impacts,  no  significant  adverse  environmental  impacts  are  foreseen.  The 
environmental assessment framework has been developed to ensure compliance with ADB’s 
Environment Policy (2002) and the Government’s environmental regulations.  
 
122.  The indigenous Veddas may also be affected by NECORD-II. In the event of their 
involvement  in  any  subprojects,  all  necessary  actions  required  under  ADB’s  Policy  on 
Indigenous Peoples (1998) and the IPDF will be taken, as similarly detailed for TAARP in para. 
74. A summary IPDF is presented in Appendix 15.
