5.  Procurement of Civil Works and Equipment 
 
123.  Procurement of goods and services under NECORD-II will be carried out in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement and the Government’s tender procedures acceptable to 
ADB. ADB’s disaster policy permits flexible interpretation of these guidelines, so that project 
activities can start promptly.  
 
124.  For civil works contracts with estimated values greater than $5 million, procurement will 
be  in  accordance  with  international  competitive  bidding  procedures.  For  contracts  with 
estimated  values  of  $5 million  and  below,  procurement  will  be  in  accordance  with  local 
competitive  bidding  (LCB)  procedures  acceptable  to  ADB.  Local  procurement  will  be  the 
preferred mode for most NECORD-II activities because of the relatively short implementation 
period, the relatively small size of most contract packages, the wide geographic spread of the 
subproject sites, and the need for local awareness of security and other frequently changing 
matters relevant to the North East. Contracts with estimated values less than $100,000 will be 
procured under LCB using post-facto approval procedures, as is currently typical for NECORD. 
LCB civil works procurement will include single-stage, two-envelope procedures where relevant, 
and bidding periods of at least 21 days.  
 
125.  Equipment and materials will be procured under international competitive bidding where 
the estimated cost is more than $500,000 equivalent, by international shopping where the 
estimated cost is between $300,000 and $500,000 equivalent, and through local procurement 
procedures acceptable to ADB where the estimated cost is $300,000 equivalent or less. Minor 
items costing less than $100,000 equivalent may be procured through direct purchase.  
 
126.  The Government has requested ADB’s approval of advance action for procurement of 
civil works, including inviting and receiving bids for contracts, for subprojects that might be 
approved for implementation prior to loan effectiveness. The Government has been advised that 
ADB’s approval of advance action would not commit ADB to financing NECORD-II.

132.  For activities where subprojects are formulated and designed during implementation,

10.  Project Review 
 
133.  NECORD-II will be regularly reviewed by the Resident Mission (at least once every 6 
months) throughout project implementation. There will also be quarterly reviews as part of the

34

V.  PROJECTS’ BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Projects’ Benefits and Impacts 
 
134.  The vast majority of the people directly affected by the tsunami disaster were at the 
lower end of the economic scale,44 partly because the districts affected tended to have high 
levels of poverty at the time of the disaster and partly because people who lived in substandard 
housing were less able to resist the onslaught of the waves. In the conflict-affected North East, 
poverty levels are estimated to be 60%–90%, much higher than in the rest of the country, 
although there are gaps in government surveys for much of the area. For both tsunami- and 
conflict-affected  people,  basic  socioeconomic  facilities  need  to  be  restored  if  affected 
communities are to recover and begin the long climb back to normalcy. A summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy is provided as Appendix 18.  
 
135.  These projects together will address the urgent needs of about 3 million people, among 
which the physically disabled, single heads of households and children feature significantly. By 
restoring sectors that form the backbone of the economy in the affected areas, NECORD-II will 
help to rebuild affected communities, and to stabilize the economic base of local populations, 
helping people to move from dependency on government support to sustainable livelihoods.  
 
136.  TAARP and NECORD-II focus on restoring preexisting facilities, allowing for technical 
improvements  and  future  demand,  based  on  a  least-cost  approach.  TAARP  also  aims  to 
strengthen the coastal environment. Taking into consideration the long years of neglect, project 
interventions focus not only on the physical rehabilitation of damaged infrastructure but also on 
the  restoration  of  the  physical  and  institutional  arrangements  for  legal,  administrative  and 
technical services.  
 
137.  Creating an environment that is conducive for vulnerable and marginalized groups in the 
conflict- and tsunami-affected areas to participate in reconstruction activities is an urgent need. 
Conflict widows, wives of the “disappeared,” single heads of households, and widowers have to 
deal with transformations in social roles that place new burdens on them. Helping them to 
become economically independent and to improve the well-being of their families involves 
reduce existing inequalities and discrimination. To this end, a gender action plan is presented in 
Appendix 19.  
 
 
 
                                                 
44  Statistics on families affected have not yet been disaggregated according to income levels. This assertion is based 
on impressions gathered during several ADB field trips to the affected areas and on monitoring reports by various 
aid agencies. Poverty levels in the affected districts are higher than the national average (head count ratio of 
22.7%) with a head count ratio of over 35% in each of the Southern districts (Galle 26%, Matara 27% and 
Hambantota 32%). Poverty statistics are not available for the North East, but can be expected to be higher due to 
the 20-year conflict.

35
B.  Assumptions, Risks, and Mitigants  
 
138.  The design of TAARP and NECORD-II incorporates a number of safeguards to improve 
and strengthen governance and institutional capacity of the EAs, the IAs, and the PMUs.  
 
139.  There  is  a  risk  that  either  or  both  projects  may  not  be  sustainable.  However,  the 
Government’s contribution is primarily through reallocation of existing budget provision and 
planned  budgetary  allocation  for  the  NECORD-II  project,  therefore  the  additional  finances 
required are limited. Further, given the situation after the tsunami, Government financing is 
limited to incremental expenditures, duties and taxes; all other components of both projects are 
100% financed by other sources, so, except for the loan of $26 million for NECORD-II, there is 
no increase in the debt burden. Except for component A of TAARP, TAARP and NECORD-II are 
being implemented through PMUs established under existing loan agreements; additional staff 
are  being  provided  through  grant  resources.  New  subprojects  must  satisfy  financial 
sustainability  criteria,  and,  as  both  projects  involve  replacing  old,  and  in  some  cases, 
depreciated assets, there is a possibility of incremental operations and maintenance savings. 
TAARP and NECORD-II are therefore deemed to be financially sustainable.  
 
140.  In responding to the tsunami, Sri Lanka’s financial and human capacities are being 
strained. The volume and scale of tsunami-related foreign assistance being provided to Sri 
Lanka could lead to governance, corruption, and administration of justice issues. The size of 
public  and  private  contributions  to  Sri  Lanka  may  exceed  the  current  capacity  of  the 
Government’s  public  administration  and  justice  systems  to  manage  the  funds,  leaving 
opportunities for individuals and public officials to take advantage of the large influx of funds and 
vulnerable people.  
 
141.  Factors mitigating governance and corruption risks include detailed subproject selection 
criteria, transparent implementation and monitoring mechanisms, specific financial controls and 
regular  and  random  audits.  Additional  budget  provisions  for  supervision  and  monitoring, 
particularly by Resident Mission staff will also serve to strengthen governance controls. In 
addition, the Government’s capacity for procurement, financial management, supervision and 
monitoring has been assessed and will be further strengthened through TAARP. In addition to 
the usual submission of annual audited reports and related financial statements to ADB, regular 
and random supervision and monitoring reviews will be undertaken. Provision has been made in 
both projects for independent annual financial audits and regular performance  audits. The 
Resident Mission is also strengthening its ability to supervise and provide guidance and training 
to PMUs. A decentralized system of private dispute resolution, and public grievance review, will 
be established under TAARP to investigate and resolve any private disputes or claims of 
impropriety against public officials relating to tsunami assistance. Manual systems of document 
storage and retrieval for personal identity documents will be modernized to minimize risks of 
false claims and corruption. Publication of tsunami assistance, procurement, and tsunami policy 
matters in all three languages (Sinhala, Tamil and English), in government newspapers and on 
a  web-site,  will  provide  the  public  with  information  and  so  improve  transparency  and 
accountability. Legal assistance will be provided to tsunami-affected people to enable them to 
avail of their legal entitlements for good governance, and to minimize disputes.  
 
142.  Provision of significant assistance to tsunami-affected people can produce tensions if it 
is perceived that different parts of the country or ethnic groups are receiving more than their fair 
share of reconstruction funds, or if other people who are in poverty or internally displaced feel 
they  are  being  forgotten.  As  a  result,  social  tensions  and  conflict  can  actually  increase, 
undermining implementation of reconstruction.

36 
143.  The peace and conflict impact assessment is available as Supplementary Appendix D. 
By fitting in the general framework of the national reconstruction plan, both projects will ensure 
that overall allocation of funds to the affected areas follows reconstruction needs and that the 
same  criteria  and  policies  are  applied  to  tsunami-  and  conflict-affected  areas.  In  addition, 
subproject selection will ensure that the beneficial outcomes are shared equitably among the 
major ethnic groups and across the target area. Both projects will make a positive contribution 
to strengthening the socioeconomic fabric of the affected areas by rebuilding key infrastructure. 
Equity  and  conflict  resolution  will  be  pursued  through  (i) selection  of  communities  and 
subprojects to ensure an ethnic balance that reasonably reflects the general ethnic composition 
of the affected areas; (ii) consultation with all major stakeholders regarding the final choice of 
subprojects;  and  (iii) consistent  application  of  the  principle  of  subsidiarity,  to  ensure  that 
recovery decisions are taken as close as possible to the affected populations, with their active 
involvement as stakeholders in the process.  
 
144.  The bureaucratic application of normal implementation procedures could result in delays 
in the rehabilitation and reconstruction of tsunami-affected areas. Disputes relating to property 
rights caused by loss of title documents, shifting of shorelines, occupation of private lands by 
squatters, elimination of property boundaries, and resettlement of displaced people may also 
cause delays.  
 
145.  To address these risks, ADB is assisting the National Procurement Agency to simplify 
the emergency procurement guidelines and the procurement guidelines for Sri Lanka. TAARP 
will engage consultants to support procurement and the planning and evaluation of subprojects, 
as requested by the Government. Existing PMUs will be used to implement the project, avoiding 
the time needed to establish new ones. They will be strengthened by adding capacity to ensure 
no  delays  in  implementation  or  processing  of  payments.  Retroactive  financing  has  been 
included so urgent activities can be funded. The legal assistance and governance measures 
mentioned above will minimize the risk of legal and documentary related disputes.  
 
146.  Another risk is that, once a period of time has passed, the national Government or 
provincial and local governments may not maintain sufficient commitment to implement both 
projects in an efficient and timely manner.  
 
147.  The Government has established TAFREN, involving high-caliber members from private 
and public sectors. It is preparing a bill to be submitted to parliament to transform TAFREN into 
an Authority that will coordinate reconstruction over a 3 to 5 year period. Reconstruction under 
TAARP  will  be  undertaken  within  this  national  framework,  while  special  mechanisms  and 
agreements are being developed for affected districts in the North East, to ensure participation 
and commitment by all stakeholders.  
 
148.  Competition  among  donors  offering  assistance  and  insufficient  coordination  in  the 
provision of assistance could lead to gaps or overlaps in sector or geographic coverage, poor 
delivery of needed benefits to tsunami-affected people, or the application of different policies or 
standards in different areas.  
 
149.  A  good  climate  for  cooperation  has  been  established  through  the  tsunami  needs 
assessment. In the second phase of the assessment, which is focusing on implementation 
mechanisms  and  coordination,  the  steering  group  has  been  expanded  to  include  bilateral 
development partners, NGOs, and the private sector. While coordinating the international NGOs 
that have raised large cash contributions will be a challenge, a good basis for cooperation has 
been laid. The Government is leading the second phase of the needs assessment, and has

37
indicated its intention to play a strong role in coordination, including listing all significant projects 
on the TAFREN website. ADB, JBIC, and the World Bank are working closely together, taking 
turns to chair reconstruction-related meetings. ADB and the World Bank have explicitly declared 
that they will make their reconstruction operations flexible, in order to play a “gap-filling” role to 
complement other development partners.  
 
150.  Price escalation is a risk. An increase in the demand for construction materials in an 
already constrained supply environment could lead to price escalation and dramatically affect 
the amount of reconstruction that can be carried out under either project. An adequate supply of 
construction  materials  (sand,  cement,  reinforcing  steel)  must  be  readily  accessible  to  the 
construction industry, in particular in the North East, where there is already a large construction 
program underway.  
 
151.  The  possibility  of  rising  prices  has  been  raised  in  a  number  of  meetings  with  the 
Government, and mitigating measures are being designed. Selective import liberalization and 
spreading  implementation  over  a  longer  period  (up  to  4  years,  depending  on  urgency  of 
interventions) will help to smooth out pressures on supply.  
 
 
VI.  SPECIFIC ASSURANCES 
 
152.  The  Government  has  given  the  following  assurances,  relevant  to  both  TAARP  and 
NECORD-II, in addition to the standard assurances. These have been incorporated into the 
legal documents.  
 
(i)  Continuity and integration. The Government will ensure the continuity of the 
implementation of NECORD and NECORD – Extension on the one hand, and 
Component H of TAARP and NECORD-II on the other, and will ensure the 
integration of the implementation of NECORD-II and Component H of TAARP. 
 
(ii)  Government administration. The project management arrangements reflect the 
present  Government  administrative  structure  that  may  change  during 
implementation. The Government will immediately notify ADB of any proposed 
change in the administrative structure in the project areas, and take all steps 
necessary to ensure that the project management arrangements are revised in 
consultation with ADB to reflect the new administrative structure and protect the 
viability of the Project(s). The Government will take all steps necessary and 
within its power to ensure that any successor project management entities enter 
into  such  project  agreements,  or  other  agreements  with  ADB,  as  ADB  may 
request.  
 
(iii)  Peace building and community reconciliation. The Government will ensure 
that  all  conflict-related  project  interventions  contribute  to  peace  building  and 
community reconciliation, and that all tsunami-related project interventions either 
contribute  to,  or  do  not  detract  from,  peace  building  and  community 
reconciliation. If any intervention has an actual or threatened negative impact on 
peace  building  and  community,  the  Government  agrees  that  ADB  shall  be 
entitled to determine whether such intervention should be continued, redesigned, 
suspended, or cancelled.

38 
(iv)  Access. The Government will ensure that staff, consultants, materials, vehicles, 
equipment, and other items required for project implementation, will be given 
reasonable access to project areas.  
 
(v)  Operation and maintenance. The Government will ensure, and will cause the 
executing  agencies,  and  implementing  agencies  to  ensure,  that  the  facilities 
provided under the Project are operated and maintained, and that adequate 
budgetary and other resources are provided for this purpose. The Government 
will also ensure that community-based organizations charged with operating and 
maintaining  facilities  provided  under  both  projects  are  provided  with  the 
necessary support and training to undertake such activities.  
 
(vi)  Subproject selection. The Government and  each Implementing Agency will 
ensure  that  all  subprojects  meet  to  ADB’s  satisfaction,  the  agreed  selection 
criteria  and  other  implementation  arrangements,  and  that  subprojects  are 
controlled and monitored to ADB’s satisfaction.  
 
(vii)  Governance and anticorruption. The Government and ADB agree to adopt a 
policy of zero-tolerance of corruption in relation to assistance provided under the 
Project(s), and by development partners. The Government will take measures to 
quickly sanction private individuals, entities, or public officials who actually, or 
attempt to take advantage of donor funds, or the loss of documents, such as the 
absence of property title documents, court records, or bank accounts.  
 
(viii)  SOE audit. The Government agrees to ensure that ADB staff are granted access 
to key books and records in order to complete an SOE audit within 6 months of 
effectiveness.  
 
(ix)  Performance  audits.  The  Government  will,  and  will  cause  each  Executing 
Agency or Implementing Agency to, engage private sector auditors, civil society 
organizations  (CSOs),  or  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  to  conduct 
semiannual performance audits during Project implementation, to determine the 
degree to which Project funds have been effectively and efficiently utilized to 
implement the Project, and achieved its objectives, outputs, and performance 
indicators. In addition, the Government will ensure that a special post completion 
performance  audit  is  conducted  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  disaster  and 
emergency  policy  to  consider  governance,  transparency,  and  financial 
accountability.  
 
(x)  ADB monitoring and compliance. The Government will allow and facilitate 
ADB’s representatives to conduct spot and random checks on (a) flow of funds 
through the imprest account, each second-generation imprest account, and each 
third-generation imprest account, and their use for the project in accordance with 
the financing agreement, (b) work-in-progress; and (c) project implementation. 
 
(xi)  Participation. The Government will ensure, or will cause each Executing Agency 
or  Implementing  Agency  to  ensure  that  CSOs,  NGOs,  and  beneficiaries  are 
involved in subproject selection, design, implementation, and monitoring.  
 
153.  In addition, the Government has given the following assurances for TAARP, in addition 
to the standard assurances, which have been incorporated into the legal documents.

39
 
(i)  Bribery and Corruption commission. Sri Lanka shall strengthen Sri Lanka’s 
Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery and Corruption established to 
investigate, and address potential corruption or irregularities related to tsunami-
assistance that may include establishing a division under the director-general of 
the Bribery and Corruption Commission or regional offices in tsunami affected 
areas, in order to investigate, and respond to, allegations of corruption in relation 
to Tsunami assistance.  
 
(ii)  Guiding principles and governance. In furtherance of the Guiding Principles of 
the  Recovery  Strategy  (2005),  which  include  communication,  transparency, 
consultation, and zero tolerance for corruption, Sri Lanka shall, in conjunction 
with ADB, do the following:  
 
(a)  establish  an  internet web-site  that  describes  or  has  links  to Tsunami 
assistance and the administration of funds under Tsunami assistance 
projects, to provide the public with information to ensure that funds are 
used for intended beneficiaries and purposes (the Tsunami Web-Site) 
and have such information published in Sinhala, Tamil and English, in Sri 
Lanka’s government newspapers; 
 
(b)  issue  or  reissue  identification  cards  to  tsunami-affected  people  and 
businesses  that  they  shall  be  required  to  use  to  obtain  tsunami 
assistance; and  
 
(c)  provide  information  concerning  tsunami-affected  people  and/or 
communities that shall receive tsunami assistance, and information for 
each contract to be procured TAARP (1) on the Tsunami Web Site, (2) in 
a readily accessible public place in each tsunami-affected area, which 
may be in each PMU office; and (3) by publishing such information in 
Sinhala, Tamil and English in Sri Lanka’s government newspapers. 
 
(iii)  Review of ADB project portfolio and disaster standards. The Government, 
the EA concerned and ADB agree to complete, within 6 months of the completion 
of the second phase of the tsunami needs assessment, a review of the active 
projects in ADB’s portfolio of projects in Sri Lanka to assess their design and 
operational methods in light of the needs assessment, in particular to consider 
how they could be improved to better avoid, or mitigate, against other natural 
disasters, and where appropriate to identify changes in the relevant project.

SUMMARY OF TSUNAMI NEEDS ASSESSMENT 
 
A.  Estimated Damage and Financing Needs 
 
1.  Overall incremental financing needs resulting from tsunami damage or destruction are 
estimated at $1.5 billion–$1.6 billion. This is in addition to the $200 million–$300 million that the 
Government estimates it has already spent, and excludes further relief expenditures. In the 
short term, most resources are required for housing, transportation infrastructure, and livelihood 
restoration for fishers, small farmers, small and microenterprises, and others. Recovery needs 
run parallel to the level of damage, with some variation, depending upon the recovery strategy 
and its intent to replace damaged assets with those of equal value, as in housing and health, or 
with upgrades to services and infrastructure, as in power, water supply and sanitation, and 
transportation (especially railways).

GUIDING PRINCIPLES OF THE RECOVERY STRATEGY 
 
1.  The allocation of domestic and international resources should be strictly guided by the 
identified  needs  and  local  priorities,  without  political,  religious,  ethnic,  or  gender 
discrimination. The recovery strategy should take into account the extent of progress in Sri 
Lanka  since  the  signing  of  the  cease-fire  agreement,  after  a  long  conflict,  and  seek  to 
strengthen the peace process. Reconstruction interventions should build confidence between 
different actors in the process. Reconstruction should similarly be sensitive to the impact on 
neighboring but unaffected communities.  
 
2.  The strategy should be based on the principle of subsidiarity: each reconstruction 
activity should be designed and implemented at the lowest competent tier of government. While 
the central Government should lead in setting standards, policies, and principles, subsidiarity 
allows for locally appropriate solutions and enables a range of subnational structures and 
organizations  to  be  directly  engaged  in  the  process.  The  recovery  plan  (which  should  be 
disaggregated to district level) will provide for capacity building and strengthening at various 
levels of governance, but especially in the districts and pradeshiya sabhas,1 as well as local 
civil-society organizations.  
 
3.  The  recovery  strategy  should  focus  on  the  victims’  medium-  and  long-term  needs. 
Therefore, enhanced and solid consultation with affected communities and stakeholders is 
essential, and communities should be empowered to make their own decisions during recovery 
and participate fully in reconstruction activities. All interventions need to respond to clearly 
identified and articulated needs of communities, respecting their religion, culture, structures, and 
customs.  This  is  especially  important  with  respect  to  the  policies  related  to  shelter  and 
relocation, which should not proceed without such full consultation. Communities should be 
assisted to return to their original homes as swiftly as possible. To maximize the speed of 
recovery, local capacities should be harnessed as far as possible.  
 
4.  Better  communication  and  transparency  are  needed  in  decision  making  and 
implementation. Mechanisms should be strengthened to ensure access to information regarding 
policies, entitlements, and implementation procedures, and to permit more regular feedback to 
implementing  authorities,  as  well  as  grievance  redress.  Similarly,  mechanisms  to  ensure 
transparency in resource use and comprehensive accounting need to be enhanced, at the 
aggregate, program, and beneficiary levels, accompanied by more effective monitoring and 
evaluation  systems,  to  permit  a  full  accounting  to  Parliament,  development  partners,  civil 
society, and the affected communities of resources deployed from all sources. All parties should 
reaffirm their policy of zero tolerance for corruption in this joint effort.  
 
5.  Reconstruction processes should reduce vulnerability to natural hazards, including 
floods,  cyclones,  and  landslides.  A  multi-hazard  risk  approach  should  be  used  during  the 
recovery  phase  to  ensure  that  communities  and  assets  are  less  vulnerable  to  impacts  of 
disasters, while balancing the social costs of excessive resettlement. It should be guided by 
international standards and best practices in design and asset management.  
 
6.  All the above considerations suggest a number of factors that will need to be built into 
the analysis of individual interventions. They should be analyzed for their potential impact on 
the cease-fire and the prospects for peace. For long-term sustainability, such interventions 
should incorporate governance, gender sensitivity, environment, resettlement and land issues, 
                                                 
1  Local government authority responsible for planning and maintenance at the community level.

Appendix 3  55
and human rights concerns. The process should be guided by international standards and best 
practice for protection, with special attention to the needs of vulnerable groups.  
 
7.  If debt relief is granted to Sri Lanka as part of the financing package, it would be 
especially important to deploy the resources transparently and to carefully monitor their use.  
 
8.  A coordinated approach is critical to ensure that the above principles are followed and 
to prevent duplication or overlap in activities. Development partners should minimize the burden 
on the overextended Government, not least by maximizing their own coordination. Coordination 
should not just be between Government and donors but involve all stakeholders, including civil 
society, the business community, and international nongovernment organizations, which have 
resources that will not pass through the Government. Local capacity would need to be created 
for such coordination.

COORDINATION OF EXTERNAL ASSISTANCE FOR POST-TSUNAMI RECONSTRUCTION 
 
1.  During the early days after the tsunami struck Sri Lanka on 26 December, a large 
amount of assistance was spontaneously offered by individuals, nongovernment organizations 
(NGOs), and the private sector. This included persons supplying food to and housing neighbors; 
corporations taking charge of organizing and supplying camps for people displaced by the 
tsunami, and domestic and international NGOs along with agencies from the United Nations 
(UN)  system  mobilizing  large  amounts  of  supplies,  food,  water,  and  other  necessities. 
Coordination was made difficult by the large number of agencies and organizations involved, 
and by size of the affected area. The UN system helped greatly in establishing the Center for 
National Operations, which coordinates the logistics and other dimensions of the relief effort.  
 
2.  The Government issued on 11 January a preliminary assessment of the casualties, 
damage, and reconstruction needs. It requested that international financial institutions such as 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  the  World  Bank,  and  Japan  Bank  for  International 
Cooperation (JBIC) jointly assess these needs to verify the Government estimates. Following a 
joint mission from 10 to 25 April 2005, during which each agency focused on a few sectors 
(roads, railways, and livelihoods for ADB; education, health, and housing for the World Bank; 
and  power,  telecommunications,  and  water  supply  and  sanitation  for  JBIC)  drafts  of  this 
multidonor assessment were circulated on 28 January and 2 February 2005. Shortly after, the 
Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam issued a draft assessment of damage in the North East. 
Interestingly, the three estimates were of the same order of magnitude, estimating total damage 
at $1.5 billion–$1.6 billion, more of it outside the southern and western provinces.  
 
3.  The  next  steps  implemented  during  February  and  March  included  (i)  a  number  of 
consultations with all stakeholders to reconcile the different estimates on the basis of common 
technical criteria, so that the Government could issue a revised needs assessment acceptable 
to all parties; (ii) a second phase of district-level consultations carried out by mixed teams 
representing the Government, external development partners, and local stakeholders, to ensure 
a consultative process in designing implementation mechanisms for reconstruction; and (iii) 
enlargement of the development partner group to include bilateral donors, UN agencies, civil 
society, and the private sector. To facilitate interaction, a representative steering committee with 
about 10 members meets weekly to closely supervise the continuing needs assessment and 
identify issues that need to be urgently addressed by the Government, while a larger meeting of 
all  development  partners  takes  place  every  2  weeks.  A  lead  agency  in  the  international 
community  and  a  board  member  of  the  Task  Force  for  Rebuilding  the  Nation  (TAFREN) 
convene  sector-level  meetings  where  the  development  partners  and  relevant  government 
ministries  can  discuss  policy  issues,  refine  reconstruction  needs  estimates,  and  develop 
financing plans.  
 
4.  ADB is the lead agency in the road sector. Together with TAFREN, the Ministry of 
Highways, and the Road Development Authority, ADB has convened three meetings, attended 
by the World Bank, JBIC, Japan International Cooperation Agency, the European Commission, 
the  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development,  and  the  Swedish  International 
Development  Cooperation  Agency,  during  which  the  overall  reconstruction  needs  were 
reviewed, the possible role of each agency discussed, and a tentative financing plan developed, 
to ensure that reconstruction activities are fully funded. Discussion was also started on the 
measures to ensure prompt and transparent implementation, the need to assess the capacity 
and possible role of the domestic contracting industry, the availability of construction materials, 
and long-term implications in terms of maintenance funding, and appropriate sequencing of the 
reconstruction in accordance to the road sector master plan being prepared.

12.  Coastal Zone Planning. The tsunami highlighted the importance of planning to avert or

C.  Component C: Road Rebuilding and Rehabilitation  
 
13.  Component  C  will  be  fully  funded  through  the  ATF.  Subprojects  will  rehabilitate, 
reconstruct, and improve road links damaged by the tsunami, and improve the transport network 
overall to improve disaster response. Access along tsunami-affected coastal roads has been 
restored,  albeit  through  immediate—and  temporary—repairs.  Road  resurfacing  and 
embankment restorations now in place are not anticipated to last beyond the next monsoon 
season. More thorough and permanent road rebuilding measures, particularly for improved 
drainage, are necessary to protect the roadway network of main transport links and feeder 
roads along the coastal belt, particularly against frequent high rains and potential flooding. The 
rehabilitation of strategic road links in the North East will improve disaster-response capacity

SUBPROJECT SELECTION PROCESS 
 
1.  The North East Community Restoration and Development Project (NECORD) uses a 
sector-style process approach to develop individual subprojects. This approach, which works 
well, will be used to prepare subprojects under component B (North East coastal community 
development), component E (Southern Province reconstruction), and component H (NECORD-
Tsunami),  under  the  Tsunami-affected  Areas  Rebuilding  Project  (TAARP)  and  subprojects 
under the North East Community Restoration and Development Project II (NECORD-II).  
 
2.  Subprojects will be initially conceived by beneficiaries, nongovernment organizations, 
government  departments,  or  newly  formed  village  rehabilitation  committees  to  restore 
community livelihoods and area infrastructure damaged or lost as a result of the tsunami or the 
decades-long  conflict.  These  subproject  proposals  will  be  first  presented  to  the  divisional 
rehabilitation  committee  (DRC)  present  in  the  affected  districts.  The  DRC  will  review  and 
evaluate  each  proposal  against  set  subproject  criteria.  If  approved,  the  proposal  will  be 
forwarded to the district rehabilitation coordinating committee (DRCC) or its equivalent, which 
will further scrutinize the subproject. The district project management unit (DPMU) will help 
these agencies prepare subproject proposals in the standard formats to be used for both 
projects.  
 
3.  After  approval  by  the  DRCC,  the  DPMU  through  the  government  agent  or  district 
secretary will present the subproject to the respective project management units (PMUs), which 
will review each subproject in detail, to ensure that the subproject (i) addresses the overall 
scope of the project, (ii) is eligible under the general and subcomponent-related criteria, (iii) will 
not create any problems in the area, (iv) has been sufficiently justified, and (v) will attain the 
desired outputs and benefits. The PMUs will (i) perform a detailed review of the subproject cost 
estimate  and  implementation  schedule;  (ii)  verify  beneficiary  contribution;  (iii)  determine  if 
contractors are available and capable of performing the work; (iv) confirm that land will be 
available; and (v) investigate any gender, social, or environmental concerns.  
 
4.  If the PMU finds that the subproject satisfies all the evaluation criteria, the proposal will 
be then forwarded to the provincial project coordinating committee (PPCC) and, 15 days before 
a PPCC meeting, circulated to ADB and the relevant secretaries, ministries, provincial, and 
district heads of departments; government agents; government security coordinators (police, 
army); nongovernment organizations; the United Nations system; and any other development 
institution  implementing  projects  in  the  area  (World  Bank,  Japan  Bank  for  International 
Cooperation, etc.).  
 
5.  The PPCC, chaired by the chief secretary, typically meets every 2 months to present 
each subproject for conditional approval. Attendees at the PCC include ADB, relevant PMU 
staff, government agents, district deputy project directors, and representatives from national 
ministries. Subprojects not approved by the PPCC will be returned to the PMU or DPMU for 
further clarification or justification. If a subproject is approved by the PPCC, the PMU will inform 
the proponent to develop the subproject to include the designs, bill of quantities, specifications, 
and  the  bid  documents.  The  final  subproject  proposal  will  then  be  forwarded  to  ADB  for 
approval. Subprojects not approved by ADB will be returned to the PMU for clarification or 
modifications  to  better  comply  with  criteria  set  forth  for  TAARP  or  NECORD-II  or  ADB 
guidelines.

A.  Legal Facilitation and Assistance  
 
1.  Tsunami-generated Legal and Documentary Issues  
 
3.  The destruction wrought by tsunami has generated legal and documentary issues for 
tsunami-affected  people  and  the  government.  Such  legal  issues  arise  from  the  loss  of 
documents, such as property titles, birth, death, and marriage certificates, court records, and 
bank account documents. They also arise from the devastating loss of life caused by the 
tsunami, as, following these mass deaths, custody, fostering, and adoption of children, and the 
inheritance of real and personal property have all arisen as problems. Issues such as insurance 
coverage, property disputes, and other entitlement issues are follow-on concerns.  
 
4.  The  Government  is  developing  a  legislative  framework  for  the  post-tsunami 
reconstruction period to enable special legal provisions for persons and property affected by the 
tsunami, and related purposes. Legislation under the framework would shorten the presumption 
of death, provide for the custody, fostering, and adoption of children, and establish provisions 
related to property rights. It would also double the penalty for any crime, if it is committed in 
relation to property or money intended for tsunami relief. The legislative framework assumes 
knowledge of the law and also establishes crimes in relation to custody of tsunami-affected 
children if certain requirements are not met.  
 
5.  To translate formal legal solutions into solutions for tsunami-affected people, will require 
them,  and  divisional  and  district  level  government  officials  (District  Secretaries,  Divisional 
Secretaries, and grama niladhari1), to understand these new legal requirements, and be able to 
proceed along appropriate channels. They will also need to have assistance to resolve any legal 
questions that may arise. Members of the law and administration of justice system in tsunami-

of decentralized legal facilitation and assistance for tsunami-related issues. As a subcomponent

would also be decentralized with a small secretariat in the North and East (Trincomalee), and

affected communities, and to service all relevant districts. Approximately seven legal facilitators 
would be engaged in the North and East, nominally one for each of the seven tsunami-affected 
districts. However, certain districts may need more assistance than others. Approximately three 
legal facilitators would also be engaged in the South, nominally one for each district in the 
South. A least an additional legal facilitator will be engaged in Colombo to serve Colombo and 
Kalutara tsunami victims, who would work together with TAARP director/coordinator. Where 
deemed appropriate by the MOJ, and agreed with ADB, legal facilitation and assistance under 
TAARP may be channeled through and support existing offices of the Legal Aid Commission. In 
the North and East where existing Legal Aid Commission offices do not exist, or for simple 
matters not requiring access to courts, legal facilitators would not be attached to the Legal Aid 
Commission.  
 
7.  This  component  coordinator/director  would  coordinate  this  subcomponent,  facilitate 
cross learning amongst the decentralized offices and monitor the conduct of legal services. This 
subcomponent would be closely coordinated with the Legal Aid Commission, its associated 
Provincial  Bar  Associations,  the  Retired  Judges  Association,  the  United  Nations  High 
Commission  on  Refugees,  the  United  Nation’s  Development  Program,  civil  society

B.  Private  Dispute  Resolution,  Public  Grievance  Review,  and  Anticorruption 
Complaints  
 
8.  The  legal  and  factual  issues  generated  by  the  tsunami,  are  also  likely  to  lead  to 
increased disputes and grievances both among tsunami-affected people, and possibly against 
government officers and departments. The Government has agreed with donors on a set of 
Guiding Principles to be followed on the path to recovery from the tsunami. Among other things, 
the Guiding Principles promote transparency, participation, accountability, and a zero-tolerance 
for  any  corruption  associated  with  tsunami  assistance.  Similarly  the  proposed  tsunami 
legislative framework would increase penalties for tsunami related crimes and improprieties. In 
furtherance of the Guiding Principles and the Government’s objectives, and to assist tsunami-
affected  people  with  disputes  and  grievances,  a  decentralized  provincial  system  of  public 
grievance  review  and  private  dispute  resolution  would  be  established  or  supported  in  the 
tsunami-affected areas and staffed by independent persons in the North and East, the South, 
and Colombo. The mechanisms would seek to resolve private disputes, and investigate claims 
of  impropriety  against  public  officials  relating  to  tsunami  assistance.  Three  proposals  for 
achieving this end are currently being considered. A combination of these mechanisms is

Appendix 7  75
viewed  as  likely  the  most  appropriate  way  to  provide  a  form  of  dispute  resolution,  public 
grievance review, and anti-corruption fora. The final mechanism may involve a combination of 
all or a different combination of these.  
 
1.  Mediation Boards 
9.  Under the Mediation Board approach, support would be provided to establish Tsunami 
Mediation Boards, in conjunction with the MOJ, and the Asia Foundation. The Asia Foundation 
has successfully worked with the Government to establish existing statutory Mediation Boards. 
Under the Mediation (Special Categories of Disputes) Act, No. 21 of 2003, the Minister of 
Justice is entitled to gazette special Mediation Boards, for special categories, special areas, and 
for specific categories of dispute. Currently under consideration, is the gazetting of Tsunami 
Mediation Boards as a special category, and defining tsunami-affected areas, and tsunami 
disputes such as property and custody disputes as specific categories.  Such special Tsunami 
Mediation Boards would also have the power to consider grievances against public officials, 
however they may not be the most effective fora to do so as sensitive issues of administrative 
law may be raised, or possibly issues of corruption or impropriety, that are not suitable for 
consensus-based solutions. Various forms of support may be required to ensure that mediation 
boards  become  functional  in  tsunami-affected  areas,  including  training  and  engaging 
consultants.  
 
2.  Tsunami  Ombudsmen  or  Extension  of  Parliamentary  Commissioner 
(Ombudsmen) to Tsunami-Affected Areas 
 
10.  ADB  has  received  strong  requests  from  Provincial  Government  to  support  a 
decentralized Office of Tsunami Ombudsmen. Under this approach, TAARP would support the 
establishment of a decentralized Office of Tsunami Ombudsmen or the extension of jurisdiction 
of the existing Parliamentary Commissioner (Ombudsmen) established under Article XIX of the 
Constitution of Sri Lanka and the Parliamentary Commissioner for Administration Act No. 17 of 
1981, to tsunami-affected areas, to deal with grievances against public officials relating to the 
tsunami.  This  approach  adopts  lessons  learned  from  the  experience  following  the  Gujarat 
earthquake in India.  In the wake of that earthquake, which killed over 20,000 people, the Indian 
High Court gave orders for speedy and effective legal aid for victims. A new ombudsmen role 
was  given  to  the  State  Legal  Services  Authority  to  look  into  complaints  against  public 
administration. Also, with the help of the Ombudsmen, special legal cells were made functional 
to facilitate legal assistance on legal issues pertaining to inheritance, family law, and property.  
 
11.  On  the  basis  of  the  Provincial  Government  proposal,  each  Office  of  Tsunami 
Ombudsmen would have a provincial coordinator, and be associated with, but separate from the 
Provincial Secretariat. Approximately four Tsunami Ombudsmen would be assigned to the North 
and East, and approximately two Tsunami Ombudsmen would be assigned to the South. Its 
staff would service all relevant districts by conducting outreach to tsunami-affected areas. The 
Office would establish the threshold criteria and procedures for handling such complaints, for 
proactively and constructively responding to them, and for providing the public with notice of 
such Office, including publishing notices in government-owned newspapers. The Office would 
be  closely  coordinated  with  the  provision  of  tsunami  legal  facilitation  and  assistance,  the 
Parliamentary  Commissioner  (Ombudsmen),  the  Retired  Judges  Association,  the  United 
Nations High Commission on Refugees, the United Nation’s Development Program on access 
to justice, civil society organizations (CSOs), and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), 
including the International Development Law Organization. and other relevant development 
partners.

12.  The possibility of implementing the functions of the Tsunami Ombudsmen by extending 
the powers and function of the existing Parliamentary Commissioner (Ombudsmen) has been 
raised. If this becomes the Government’s preferred approach, ADB would ensure that it serves 
the needs initially requested by the Provincial Government. In such a case, TAARP would 
support the Parliamentary Commissioner (Ombudsmen) to go on circuit to the tsunami-affected 
areas. 
 
13.  The benefits of an ombudsmen approach to public grievance review and corruption 
redressal are clear and recognized by many stakeholders. However, there are certain legal 
challenges in implementing an Office of Tsunami Ombudsmen in Sri Lanka, that would need to 
be overcome for it able to be established quickly enough to be an effective response to public 
grievances in the post- tsunami context. This approach remains tabled and under consideration, 
but the other two approaches that work with existing institutions in Sri Lanka are currently 
preferred as more likely to be able to be used to provide a timely response.  
 
3.  Bribery and Corruption Commission 
 
14.  New  Commissioners  to  the  Commission  to  Investigate  Allegations  of  Bribery  and 
Corruption (the “Bribery and Corruption Commission”) were appointed in March 2005. The 
Government has agreed that the administrative branch that conducts investigations, and acts 
under the Director General in the Bribery and Corruption Commission would be strengthened by 
formation of a tsunami unit, which may also have regional offices in tsunami affected areas. The 
Bribery and Corruption Commission would thus serve tsunami-affected areas. TAARP would 
support this strengthening.  
 
C.  Judicial Training Workshops and Legal Awareness 
 
15.  Magistrates, district court, and high court judges, in tsunami-affected areas, need to be 
familiarized with the property and custody legal issues likely to arise post-tsunami, and the post-
tsunami legislative framework when enacted. The types of legal issues that are likely to arise 
are anticipated, however the details of the sorts of disputes have not yet been identified, and 
may be investigated as part of the data-collection process described in part F below. Based on 
more detailed data identifying the nature of tsunami-related legal disputes likely to come up in 
courts, in conjunction with the MOJ and Sri Lanka’s judicial training institute, TAARP would 
coordinate  a  series  of  magistrate,  judicial  training,  officer,  and  public  legal  awareness 
workshops in or for the tsunami-affected areas.  
 
16.  The tsunami legislative framework presumes knowledge of the law and imposes jail 
penalties for violations such as holding custody of an “orphan” without complying with certain 
procedures.  Legal  awareness  workshops  will  be  coordinated  for  district  officials,  local  law 
enforcers, and the public, in conjunction with, or independently from the judicial workshops for  
tsunami related issues.  
 
D.  Replacement Documents  
 
17.  The Registrar General’s Department, within the Ministry of Public Administration and 
Home Affairs, oversees the registration of births, deaths, marriages, private property titles, and 
liens on moveable property. It is responsible for replacing documents destroyed in the tsunami, 
original birth, death, marriage, immoveable property liens, and property title documents either in 
the possession of tsunami victims, or at district or divisional offices of the Registrar General.

Appendix 7  77
18.  In Galle alone, as of 29 March 2005, 8,000 applications had been made for replacement 
documents, of which only 2000 have been provided to tsunami affected people. A copy of all 
birth, death, and marriage records held by individuals, and held in district or divisional offices is 
retained in the Central Record Room of the Registrar General in Colombo. However, the Central 
Record Room is manually sorted, and categorized by registration numbers. If individuals who 
apply for replacement documents do not know their registration number, many records must be 
sorted to provide a replacement. In many cases it would appear to be an almost impossible 
task. The Central Record Room has limited photocopiers, and limited basic filing equipment.  
The essential post-tsunami reissuance of documents would appear not likely to get done, unless 
changes are made.  
 
19.  TAARP will provide support to the Registrar General’s Department in reissuing birth, 
death,  marriage,  and  property  title  records  to  tsunami-affected  people,  and  issuing  death 
certificates,  by  computerizing  their  Central  Record  Room  and  purchasing  filing  cabinets, 
photocopiers, scanners, and similar office facilities, if required. This would be coordinated with 
the Office of the President (discussed in part F below) who are attempting to centralize data 
collection efforts to minimize duplications of efforts and to limit the extent to which tsunami 
affected people are approached by multiple government agencies and NGOs for similar data 
collection  questions.  Following  preparatory  work  on  TAARP,  the  Office  of  President’s 
coordination  now  includes  the  Department  of  Registration  of  Persons,  and  the  Registrar 
General.  Computer  automation  of  the  central  record  room  will  use  software  for  efficiently 
capturing  and  retrieving  archived  documents.  ADB  may  support  the  purchase  of 
computers, and will support networking and connectivity of such equipment, as well as 
the purchase of office items. It would also support mobile-van services to tsunami-affected 
districts, which may include retroactive financing. Computer automation of registration would 
reduce the extent that individuals could falsely obtain multiple registrations.  
 
E.  Replacement or Issue of Identification Cards  
 
20.  The Department of the Registration of Persons, within the Ministry of Public Security 
Law and Order, issues identification cards. Identification cards are used in Sri Lanka to open 
bank accounts, obtain entry to certain places, to obtain passports, etc. Following the tsunami, 
thousands of identity cards need to be replaced, and tsunami-affected people issued with new 
identification. Ensuring that all tsunami-affected people have an identity card that they use to 
obtain assistance is an additional measure to minimize false claims for assistance. As of 1 
March 2005, following mobile teams sent to tsunami-affected areas in Kalutara, Galle, Matara, 
Hambantota, Trincomalee and Kilinochchi Districts, over 30,000 applications for identity cards 
for tsunami victims had been received. It is anticipated that over 100,000 applications would be 
received when all the mobile services are completed.  
 
21.  The processing of applications including tracing and perusal of index cards and past 
applications is an essential part of the process. It is both time consuming and labor intensive.  
The overwhelming majority of applications are from people who have lost their identity cards 
and  do  not  remember  their  identity  card  number.  This  causes  additional  work  for  the 
department. As the records are not computerized, the task of tracing all records has to be 
attended to manually. The records pertaining to more than 20.5 million identity cards are stored 
in three different locations in Keppetipola, Nugegoda and Barnes, adding to difficulties as the 
normal work of the department has to be attended simultaneously. However, the issuing of 
identity cards for tsunami victims cannot be delayed. Department staff are being deployed after 
working hours and during week-ends. It is expected that the extra remuneration payable to the

staff deployed for this work will be in the region of Rs1,000,000 at the rate of Rs10.00 per 
application and even with additionally deployed staff there is no surety that the records will be 
located. The Department does not have funds to meet this expenditure, nor associated needed 
office  facilities  services  such  as  computers  and  photocopiers.  This  subcomponent  would 
support the Department of the Registration of Persons, in a similar way to that done for the 
Registrar  General.  In  addition  to  promoting  coordination,  and  joint  data  collection  efforts, 
TAARP would computerize data held by the Department of the Registration of Persons, to allow 
it to be matched with data obtained from tsunami-affected persons. To further limit the use and 
abuse of tsunami assistance funds by tsunami-affected individuals, a temporary identification 
card would be issued and connected to a tsunami-affected individual’s details. By doing this, the 
extent to which false claims could be reduced. In addition, mobile-van services and outreach to 
tsunami-affected districts, would be supported if necessary.

present financial statements, track procurement contract awards, including its amount, and

G.  NGO Accountability

but may be selected as community infrastructure subprojects and financed by TAARP under

the tsunami. The MOJ has assessed the damage to courts and labor tribunals, prisons, and

SPECIAL FEATURES OF PROJECT DESIGN FOR GOOD GOVERNANCE  
AND ANTICORRUPTION MEASURES 
 
1.  The risks of weak governance and corruption in the Tsunami-affected Areas Rebuilding 
Project  (TAARP)  and  the  North  East  Community  Restoration  and  Development  Project  II 
(NECORD-II) are a concern. ADB’s interventions in these projects seek to comprehensively 
address these risks and balance the need for expeditious processing of ADB’s assistance, while 
ensuring and maintaining the integrity of the post-tsunami and post-conflict reconstruction and 
rehabilitation programs through a number of special project design features.  
 
A.  Governance and Corruption Risks  
 
2.  Ensuring  good  governance  and  anticorruption  measures  are  key  features  of  ADB’s 
poverty reduction strategy and are priorities in all ADB-financed projects. The volume and scale 
of foreign assistance now being contributed to Sri Lanka could lead to governance breakdown 
and weaknesses in the law and administration of justice system. The size of public donor and 
private contributions provide opportunities for private individuals and public officials to take 
advantage of people made vulnerable by the tsunami. The loss of documents and records, such 
as  property  titles,  birth  certificates,  death  certificates,  and  identification  cards  make  such 
opportunities even more likely. Individuals have already reportedly assumed multiple personal 
identities to register for relief at more than one location. The final resolution of property disputes, 
and the award of custody of children can only be resolved in Sri Lankan courts, which is likely to 
encumber  a  legal  system  already  overburdened  with  delayed  cases,  and  may  exacerbate 
inadequacies.  
 
B.  Governance and Anticorruption Strategies  
 
3.  TAARP and NECORD-II seek to confront these risks with a series of measures that 
emphasize  the  transparency,  participation,  and  accountability  required  under  the  disaster 
policy.1 
 
1.  Accounting and Procurement  
 
4.  Accounting Capacity. The capacity of the projects’ project management units and 
district project management units to follow good accounting practices is being strengthened by 
hiring more accountants. Accounting training will be provided to further strengthen capacity. 
Good financial practice supports sound management and governance.  
 
5.  Procurement. ADB has been advising the National Procurement Agency on measures 
to streamline and accelerate procurement without sacrificing transparency and competition. 
Consultant  support  will  be  provided  through  TAARP  to  continue  and  formalize  procedural 
improvements without compromising integrity.  
 
2.  Supervision and Monitoring  
 
6.  Supervision  and  Monitoring.  As  required  by  the  disaster  policy,  TAARP  and 
NECORD-II provide for additional supervision and monitoring. Internal regular and random 
supervision and monitoring are required. Specific requirements for community participation in

RESETTLEMENT FRAMEWORK 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  The resettlement framework sets out the broad scope, policy, and procedures for the 
formulation of resettlement plans for subprojects and investments under the two projects.  
 
2.  The  proposed  projects  will  support  the  Government  of  Sri  Lanka  in  the  recovery, 
reconstruction, and rehabilitation process in tsunami-affected areas nationwide and in conflict-
affected areas of the Northern and Eastern provinces. The recovery and rebuilding process 
involves  the  reconstruction  and  rehabilitation  of  housing,  health  facilities,  schools,  water 
supplies,  irrigation  facilities,  roads,  coastal  structures,  fisheries  infrastructure,  government 
offices, and institutional infrastructure. Most of the works associated with rebuilding the above 
will occur on preexisting sites. However, some rebuilding in the course of either project might 
take place on government land or land acquired under the Land Acquisition Act.  
 
3.  Damage caused by the tsunami on individual properties and livelihoods has exacerbated 
the damage caused by ethnic conflicts in some locations in the Northern and Eastern provinces. 
According to the initial needs assessments,1 the tsunami has destroyed about 100,000 houses, 
and partially damaged over 46,000 houses. Pre-tsunami ethnic conflicts had damaged over the 
50,000 houses in the conflict-affected areas.2 The tsunami-affected people live in temporary 
camps. The Government’s initiative for the tsunami-affected people is to provide (i) livelihood 
grant to restart livelihoods, (ii) a housing grant and loan to rebuild the destroyed or damaged 
house,  and  (iii)  a  plot  of  land  for  those  who  are  relocated.  The  Tsunami-affected  Areas 
Rebuilding  Project  (TAARP)  will  assist  the  Government  in  returning  tsunami-affected 
households in situ—to their original places of residence—through cash grants in accordance 
with current tsunami housing reconstruction policy for rebuilding their shelter. As part of the 
community  development subcomponents under the TAARP, assistance will be provided to 
households for assistance in restarting their livelihoods. TAARP will rebuild damaged basic, 
community, and institutional infrastructure in the tsunami-affected areas. Through the North 
East Community Restoration and Development Project II (NECORD-II), the Government will 
reconstruct damaged in conflict-affected areas, assist the rehabilitation of basic needs such as 
health, education, irrigation, agriculture, replace damaged or destroyed shelter in situ, and 
rebuild community infrastructure and income-generating programs.  
 
4.  The tsunami affected a few communities of coastal Veddas—indigenous people—in the 
Trincomalee district of the Eastern Province. The TAARP will address their specific needs, if 
necessary,  in  the  context  of  their  specific  social  and  cultural  system.  In  such  case,  an 
indigenous peoples development plan (IPDP) will be prepared to address the potential impacts 
on these communities according to the agreed indigenous peoples development framework 
(IPDF), included as Appendix 15.

5.  Combined, the projects will assist the reconstruction and rehabilitation of about 7,000 
houses, enabling some tsunami-affected households to return to their original residences. The 
beneficiary selection and housing grants will be in accordance with the Government’s policy3 on 
tsunami reconstruction. The housing program will be supplemented by the programs of basic 
social infrastructures, livelihood improvement, and gender development. Social infrastructure 
includes the rebuilding of damaged roads, coastal structures, and fisheries harbors.  
 
B.  Project Components with Resettlement Impacts  
 
6.  Housing.  To  the  extent  possible,  the  Government  will  assist  the  tsunami-affected 
households  to  rebuild  their  dwellings,  where  they  existed  when  the  tsunami  hit  them  in 
December 2004. The housing program is of two components: a cash grant and access to easy-
term  loans.4  Each  tsunami-affected  household  at  eligible  locations  will  receive  a  phased 
payment of a cash grant (different grants for fully damaged and partially damaged houses), and 
an additional housing loan. The timing, pace, content, and extent of house rebuilding will be 
managed  by  the  household  with  the  assistance  of  civil-society  organizations  (CSOs)  and 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs). The Government will provide relevant information on 
possible house type plans, construction costs and techniques, and access to demonstration 
units5. Local CSOs will coordinate the housing program, and such coordination will include 
interface between households, local governments, building material suppliers and local micro 
and small-scale building contractors.  
 
7.  Some locations may need large-scale reconstruction, and as a result, will require the 
engagement of centralized and large-scale building contractors (footnote 5). Rehabilitation of 
such communities may require the relocation of all households. For such relocation, the Urban 
Development  Authority  (UDA)  has  identified  Government  land,  Government  agency-owned 
land, and private land. Most of the land for relocation will be unoccupied Government land. In 
the event that suitable Government land is not available, UDA will acquire land under Land 
Acquisition Act through consultation and negotiations and will pay the land its replacement 
value, as prescribed by the national involuntary resettlement policy. In such cases, the guiding 
principles will be, to the extent possible, to keep the tsunami-affected communities at their 
original locations. The main guiding principle in allocating land plots is that all tsunami-affected 
households will be given to both titled and non-titled households.  
 
8.  The  following  operational  principles  will  be  applied  in  implementing  the  above 
community-level programs:  
 
 (i)  At resettlement sites, tsunami-affected communities will involve in selecting new 
locations for community infrastructure and housing and in deciding layout and 
infrastructure  designs.  This  process  will  be  facilitated  by  CSOs,  chosen  by 
tsunami-affected communities.  
(ii)  Each household will supervise and manage the construction of its dwelling at its 
original site or on the assigned land plot.

(iv)  The elderly, the disabled, households headed by women, and/or households that

(v)  Titles of new land plots, housing and other structures and livelihood assistance

9.  In housing programs, particularly in large-scale community-driven housing programs, the 
construction process will be streamlined. Three processes in this regard are critical: (i) a large 
number of tsunami-affected households lost their land titles, bank documents, and identification 
cards. This situation is compounded by the fact that in some districts land registries were 
damaged, and official records were destroyed by the tsunami. In such cases, a mechanism will 
be established to ensure that such factors would not unduly delay recovery and reconstruction. 
(ii) A concise, clear and simplified building codes applicable to the reconstruction process will be 
developed. Such building codes will be adopted and will be widely disseminated among the 
tsunami-affected households. (iii) An accelerated process to institutionalize the issuance of 
building permits at local, district, and provincial levels will be established.  
 
10.  Three issues in respect of construction sector facilitation that need special attention are 
(i) supply of skilled labor at construction sites: initiatives will be provided to support the training 
of skilled construction workers (such as masons, carpenters, plumbers and electricians) through 
vocational training institutional network and through CSOs; (ii) construction materials: Sri Lanka 
will  require  the  support  of  materials  and  equipment  supply  chains;  (iii)  environmental 
management: an appropriate environmental management response for lime production will be 
installed.  
 
11.  Assistance to Tsunami-affected Local Authorities. At most tsunami-affected coastal 
areas,  local  authorities  often  do  not  have  the  requisite  institutional  capacity  to  effectively 
manage  large-scale  emergency  assistance  programs.  Therefore,  as  part  of  the  recovery 
process, these local authorities will be assisted in developing and mainstreaming consultative 
and inclusive recovery strategies. Project assistance to local authorities includes resources for 
design,  rehabilitation  and/or  reconstruction  of  local  infrastructure  such  as  minor  roads, 
pathways, solid waste management, and street lighting.  
 
12.  Public  infrastructure  that  would  receive  assistance  include  national  road,  access 
roads, minor road, culverts, drains, small-scale water supply and sanitation facilities, solid waste 
management,  small-scale  fisheries  related  infrastructure  such  as  net  repair  sheds, 
market/auction halls, and cold storage facilities. Although the majority of construction would 
involve the reconstruction of infrastructure at its pre-tsunami location, some could necessitate 
permanent or temporary land acquisition.

13.  Coastal  Resources  Management.  The  TAARP  will  repair  damage  to  coastal 
stabilization structures and harbor backwaters in the Southern and Western provinces and 
enhance coastal protection and environmental management along the coast by reestablishing 
green  zones  or  green  belts  through  intensive  forestation  with  coastal  vegetation.  The 
enforcement of tsunami rebuilding policy and guidelines along the tsunami-affected coast will 
displace  persons,  especially  the  squatters  and  encroachers.  Land  acquisition  for  coastal 
resource management, if necessary, will follow the resettlement principles outlined above in 
para 8.  
 
14.  Livelihood  Restoration.  Under  both  projects,  livelihood  restoration  support  will  be 
provided to enable tsunami-affected and conflict-affected households to rebuild their livelihood 
sources or to learn new employment skills. This will be done by reviving local economies 
through the creation of jobs for locally-based skilled and unskilled labor. Livelihood support 
interventions  include  advisory  services  to  identify  and  develop  suitable  livelihood  options 
including small-scale enterprises, skills development, and transfer of technology. Some of these 
advisory services will be linked with microcredit. Asset replacement support for disadvantaged 
groups on a very competitive basis will also a part of this project component.  
 
C.  Policy Framework and Entitlements 
 
15.  This resettlement framework is based on ADB’s involuntary resettlement policy and 
disaster and emergency assistance policy, and the national involuntary resettlement policy of Sri 
Lanka6. The resettlement framework sets out the broad scope, policy, and procedures for 
screening and formulation of resettlement plans for subprojects and investments under both 
projects. The detailed scope of individual subprojects has not yet been defined; however, the 
executing agencies (EAs) will be required to prepare, as needed, resettlement plans according 
to this RF, and Government and ADB guidelines for subprojects with any resettlement impacts.7  
 
16.  Involuntary resettlement principles applicable to the TAARP and NECORD-II are derived 
from ADB’s involuntary resettlement policy, the Government’s national involuntary resettlement

assistance.

absence of replacement land, cash compensation is the option for all affected

D.  Procedure of Formulating a Resettlement Plan  
 
19.  In preparing a resettlement plan (RP), the following procedures will be followed: 
 
(i)  Conduct consultations with all stakeholders to obtain inputs regarding how to avoid 
or minimize involuntary resettlement impacts and identify needs and preferences of 
APs when formulating the RP.  
(ii)  Undertake  a  census,  asset  inventory,  and  detailed  measurement  surveys.  A 
socioeconomic survey of a sample population will also be undertaken to identify 
different  categories  of  APs,  based  on  the  degree  and  scale  of  impacts  of  the 
subproject on them.  
(iii)  Formulate a time-bound schedule for RP implementation, procedures for grievance 
redress, monitoring and evaluation (both internal and external). 
(iv)  Develop an entitlements matrix to outline entitlements of all tsunami-affected persons 
including non-titled persons, e.g., squatters, encroachers, and informal dwellers. If 
new  categories  of  APs  and  types  of  losses  are  identified  during  project 
implementation,  appropriate  entitlements  will  be  added  to  the  resettlement 
framework. 
(v)  Draft RP will be disclosed to all APs. The EA will review and approve it before 
submitting to ADB for review and approval. It will be disclosed to all APs and posted 
on ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Website.  
(vi)  The  RP  approved  by  EA  and  ADB  will  be  implemented  before  award  of  any 
construction contracts of the subproject.

20.  The executing agencies of TAARP and NECORD-II will be the ministries of finance and 
planning; relief, rehabilitation, and reconstruction; highways; fisheries and aquatic resources;

Conservation  Department,  National  Water  Supply  and  Drainage  Board  and  National

Subprojects will be selected on the basis of established criteria, as established in Appendixes 
5a and 5b. Formulation, implementation, and monitoring of RPs of subprojects will be the 
responsibility of the concerned EA and IA and their PMU, which will work under the overall

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Tsunami-affected Areas Rebuilding Project (TAARP) and the North East Community 
Restoration  and  Development  Project  II  (NECORD-II)  aim  to  support  the  Government’s 
rebuilding efforts in the wake of the tsunami, and continuing rehabilitation efforts in the conflict-
affected areas in the North East, respectively. Subprojects will be implemented through project 
implementation units (PMUs) under various implementing agencies, all now in existence for 
other ongoing ADB-financed projects. While most of the subprojects are similar in scope to 
ongoing projects, a few that are not have been introduced for possible implementation under 
TAARP and NECORD-II. This initial environmental examination has been developed for the 
broad framework of TAARP and NECORD-II, as they address similar reconstruction needs and 
use  similar  approaches  to  implement  the  works.  However,  during  subproject  formulation, 
environmental  concerns  will  be  studied  in  further  detail.  An  environmental  assessment 
framework has been developed (Appendix 12) to ensure that subprojects follow environmental 
assessment  procedures,  in  keeping  with  the  Government  of  Sri  Lanka’s  environmental 
assessment regulations and ADB’s Environment Policy (2002).  
 
B.  Description of the Project 
 
2.  The TAARP and NECORD-II will reconstruct damaged or destroyed infrastructure and 
essential services primarily by providing civil works, equipment, and consulting services. TAARP 
will introduce measures to enhance environmental protection along the coastal belt. Subprojects 
include  rehabilitating  damaged  roads  ranging  from  classes  A  to  E;1  rehabilitating  basic 
community infrastructure (schools, hospitals, housing, health facilities, and local government 
buildings,  including  small  markets);  rehabilitating  irrigation  schemes;2  preparing  and 
implementing  village  development  plans;  providing  support  for  livelihood  activities; 
reconstructing coastal protection interventions such as groins, revetments, and embankments; 
rehabilitating damaged harbors; enhancing coastal protection by reestablishing vegetation in 
coastal  zones;  and  expanding  and  rehabilitating  community  water  supply  and  sanitation 
schemes. TAARP will support rural microfinance credit schemes.  
 
C.  Description of the Environment 
 
1.  Physical Resources 
 
3.  Sri Lanka sits on a narrow continental shelf 45 kilometers (km) wide in the northeastern 
and northwestern coasts and 8 km along the southeastern and eastern coasts. The country has 
an  area  of  44,250  square  kilometers.  The  northern  shelf  merges  with  India,  forming  an 
extensive shallow bank consisting of the Gulf of Mannar, Palk Strait, and Pedro Bank. The 
coastline is 1,770 km.  
 
4.  The  climate  is  influenced  by  two  monsoon  and  two  inter-monsoon  periods.  The 
southwest monsoon, which occurs from May to September, is associated with cyclonic wind 
circulations or depressions and is marked by heavy rainfall, especially in the southwestern 
seaboard. The northeast monsoon occurs from December to February, and is characterized by 
heavy rainfall more or less confined in the northeastern half of the country, with wind generally

coming from an easterly direction. Wind becomes generally light during the two inter-monsoon 
periods—March to April, and October to November. The average temperature of the project 
area ranges from 290C to 370C.  
 
2.  Ecological Resources 
 
5.  The natural ecosystems within the coastal zone are diverse and include lagoons and 
estuaries, coral reefs, mangrove swamps, seagrass beds, other wetlands and dune systems. 
The country’s principal coral reef systems are composed of fringing reefs close to the shore. 
Several offshore reefs are on the continental shelf off the northwestern coast. Destructive 
fishing practices and human-induced activities such as siltation and pollution have led to the 
destruction of the coral reefs. Cumulative damage to mangroves in Sri Lanka has resulted from 
overutilization of the resource and the transformation of large areas for other uses. Mangroves 
have been converted for aquaculture, coconut, and paddy cultivation, and reclaimed for housing 
and urban expansion. The impact the tsunami has had on these natural systems is yet to be 
studied.  
 
6.  Sri Lanka is estimated to have over 23,800 hectares of salt marsh lands. Salt marshes in 
the north are found mostly on tidal flats, while in the south, they occur mainly in low areas on the 
sheltered sides of sand dunes. The coastal marshes and wetlands are feeding grounds for 
migratory waterfowl. Within the tsunami- and conflict-affected areas, around 15 sites have been 
formally designated as protected areas and sanctuaries.  
 
7.  Cultural landmarks include temples, mosques, churches, and 16th–17th-century Dutch 
and Portuguese forts.  
 
3.  Human and Economic Development 
 
8.  The main economic activities of the affected communities are fisheries and tourism. The 
contribution of fisheries, hotels, and restaurants together is only 3% to GDP. However, the 
coastal  economy  is  largely  dependent  on  these  sectors  and  many  of  the  small  informal 
businesses in these areas also service these industries. The agriculture sector in these regions, 
which was less affected, consists of small-scale farmers. The coastal communities are largely 
poor, with the North East communities suffering from the added burden of a 20-year civil war.  
 
9.  Human development in Sri Lanka is higher than in comparable countries, with a literacy 
rate of 92% and life expectancy at 73 years. The net enrolment rate in primary education is 
96%. Even in the poor regions the level of human development is satisfactory due to the 
universal free education and health policies that the country has followed for a long time. 
However, the quality of facilities differs greatly across the regions, and poor communities have 
less access to higher education and good medical services.  
 
D.  Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
 
10.  As the main focus of each project is to rehabilitate or rebuild infrastructure and essential 
services  damaged  or  destroyed  either  by  the  tsunami  or  the  conflict,  an  overall  positive 
environmental impact is expected.  
 
11.  Reconstruction works of almost all infrastructure facilities, including harbors, markets, 
schools, other than some individual housing, will be at original sites. Roads will be through the 
original right-of-way, and a change in alignment or widening of roads is not anticipated. Coastal
