stabilization  will  focus  on  replacing  displaced  boulders  and  reconstructing  groins  and 
revetments. Water supply and sanitation subprojects will focus on repairing damaged structures 
and extending the coverage. Negative environmental impacts during construction, including 
increased dust, noise, temporary disruption of traffic flow, and soil erosion, will be short term 
and can be mitigated by suitable construction practices. Measures to minimize the impacts will 
be included in the contract documents. A resettlement framework has been developed to ensure 
that any resettlement that may occur under the projects will follow the procedures laid out in

12.  Apart  from  reconstruction  works,  measures  to  improve  the  environment  will  be 
incorporated  into  the  subproject  designs.  Reestablishing  coastal  green  belts  with  suitable 
vegetation is proposed. Immediately after the tsunami, NGOs and local government authorities 
helped  sort  and  dispose  of  the  large  quantities  of  waste.  While  the  tsunami-affected 
communities have salvaged whatever building materials that could be reused, large quantities of 
construction debris—broken bricks, concrete—remain stockpiled. It is proposed, where feasible, 
to reuse this as core material to rebuild groins and revetments, or to crush and reuse it as sub-
base material for access roads to be constructed under TAARP and NECORD-II. This will help 
minimize  problems  of  waste  disposal  and  the  impacts  on  natural  resources  as  more  raw 
material is used for reconstruction.  
 
E.  Institutional Requirements, Environmental Mitigation, and Monitoring Plan 
 
13.  In  keeping  with  the  environmental  assessment  requirements  of  the  Government 
stipulated  in  the  National  Environmental  Act  and  Coast  Conservation  Act  and  ADB’s 
Environment Policy (2002), subprojects determined as requiring environmental assessments will 
need  approval  of  the  project  approving  agency  and  ADB.  An  environmental  assessment 
framework  has  been  developed  to  help  determine  which  subprojects  will  require  an  initial 
environmental examination (IEE).  
 
14.  Preparation of the IEE and obtaining the necessary approvals will be the responsibility of 
the PMU. The PMU must also ensure that mitigation measures identified in the environmental 
management plan are incorporated during implementation. Contract documents shall describe 
the environmental obligations of the contractor and penalties for noncompliance. While most 
PMUs under these projects are supported by consultants, or have their own staff to monitor the 
implementation of the environmental management plan, they may obtain additional consultancy 
services if required.  
 
15.  Quarterly  progress  review  reports  submitted  by  the  implementing  agencies  to  ADB 
should include the progress of environmental monitoring and highlight any other environmental 
issues that may have arisen during implementation, and measures taken to address the issues.  
 
F.  Public Consultation and Information Disclosure 
 
16.  Given the emergency nature of TAARP, detailed public consultations in tsunami-affected 
areas  could  not  be  held  although  public  consultations  and  beneficiary  participation  are  a 
necessary and integrated initial step in subproject selection. However, during the tsunami fact-
finding and needs assessment missions, consultations were held with government officials, the 
Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, NGOs, other bilateral organizations, and a few tsunami-
affected persons.  
17.  In the planning and implementation of subprojects, beneficiary communities shall be 
consulted to ensure that their concerns and needs are addressed in the rehabilitation of the

works. During the consultation, project information should be shared with the beneficiaries. All 
contractual  information  on  ongoing  subprojects  should  be  clearly  posted  at  subproject 
construction sites, including the exact contract amount and dates. All environmental documents 
are subject to public disclosure; therefore, these documents should be made available to the 
public, in accordance with ADB’s public communications policy. 
 
G.  Environmental Assessment and Review Procedures of Subprojects 
 
18.  The environmental assessment and review procedures are described in Appendix 14. All 
subprojects related to rehabilitation of class-A and -B roads, class-C to -E roads over 5 km, 
local access roads, harbors, and community water supply and sanitation schemes, and to 
resettlement of communities have been classified as category-B projects and require an IEE. 
Other subprojects will be subject to environmental screening. Subprojects will be designed so 
that they comply with ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) and are in keeping with the relevant 
governmental laws, regulations, and standards.  
 
H.  Conclusion 
 
19.  The  TAARP  and  NECORD-II  focus  primarily  on  reconstruction  and  rehabilitation  of 
infrastructure. Short-term, reversible, minor negative impacts are anticipated as a result of 
construction. These can be mitigated by adopting good construction practices and incorporating 
mitigatory measures during design and construction, and including clauses in the contract 
documents. Significant environmental benefits are anticipated through subproject interventions, 
including improvements in water supply and sanitation, coastal protection, and provision of 
basic services. TAARP and NECORD-II are environmental category-B projects. Subprojects will 
be  subject  to  environmental  screening.  The  IEE  shows  that  no  significant  adverse 
environmental impacts are foreseen to be associated with the proposed rehabilitation work and, 
therefore,  a  full-scale  environmental  impact  assessment  of  further  impacts  of  TAARP  or 
NECORD-II is unlikely to be required.

TSUNAMI-AFFECTED AREAS REBUILDING PROJECT AND  
NORTH EAST COMMUNITY RESTORATION AND DEVELOPMENT PROJECT II 
 
INDIGENOUS PEOPLES DEVELOPMENT FRAMEWORK 
 
 
A.  Introduction  
 
1.  The tsunami seriously damaged the Western and Northeastern coastal areas of Sri 
Lanka. A needs assessment has been completed to assess the damages to property, livelihood 
and infrastructure. In a response a request for emergency assistance, ADB has prepared two 
interlinked  projects:  Tsunami-affected  Areas  Rebuilding  Project  (TAARP)  and  North  East 
Community Restoration and Development Project II (NECORD II) comprising components of 
roads, community infrastructure and shelter, livelihood support, water supply and sanitation, and 
coastal protection. Under these two projects, it is proposed to conduct socioeconomic surveys 
to  identify  and  evaluate  the  socioeconomic  conditions  of  local  communities,  including 
indigenous communities who live in marginalized small coastal communities, and to provide 
reconstruction assistance to rebuild damaged properties and community infrastructure as well 
as livelihood sources through a participatory strategy. The first step is to identify priority areas 
for immediate interventions. About 150 households of indigenous people (Veddas) have thus far 
been  identified  as affected  by  the  tsunami. Many  more  Veddas  living  in  Trincomalee  and 
Batticaloa  districts  might  have  also  been  affected  by  the tsunami;  the  number  of  affected 
indigenous  peoples  could  increase  once  the  socioeconomic  surveys  are  completed.  This 
indigenous peoples development framework (IPDF) has been formulated as the basis for any 
indigenous peoples development plans (IPDPs) that may be needed to address indigenous 
peoples’ issues arising from the subprojects. The IPDF is intended to guide the selection and 
preparation  of  subprojects  under  either  project  to  ensure  better  distribution  of  benefits  to 
indigenous peoples, and rebuild their lost income sources and dwellings.  
 
B.  Indigenous Groups 
 
2.  ”Indigenous peoples” refers to a population with social, cultural, economic, and political 
traditions and institutions distinct from the mainstream or dominant society or culture. ADB’s 
indigenous peoples policy uses the following characteristics to define indigenous peoples: (i) 
descent from population groups present in a given area; (ii) maintenance of cultural and social 
identities separate from dominant society and culture; (iii) self-identification and identification by 
others  as  being  part  of  distinct  cultural  group;  (iv)  linguistic  identity  different  from  that  of 
dominant society; (v) social, cultural, economic and political traditions and institutions distinct 
from dominant culture; (vi) economic systems more oriented towards traditional productions 
systems rather than mainstream; and (vii) unique ties and attachments to traditional habitats 
and ancestral territories. Essentially, indigenous peoples have a social and cultural identity 
distinct  from  the  main  society,  which  makes  them  vulnerable  to  being  overlooked  in 
development processes.  
 
3.  The coastal Vedda’s communities retain a number of social and cultural traditions and 
distinct economic activities such as group hunting, food gathering and fishing. As such, the 
Veddas are, according to ADB’s policy, considered indigenous peoples.

112  Appendix 15   
C.  Objective of Indigenous Peoples Development Framework  
 
4.  The  objective  of  IPDF  is  to  ensure  that  indigenous  peoples  living  in  coastal 
communities—in this case, the Veddas—will have opportunities to participate in and benefit 
equally from either project, thereby enabling them to reconstruct and improve their livelihoods, 
dwellings, and public facilities.  
 
5.  The objectives of the IPDF are the following: 
 
(i)  Promote  active  participation  of  indigenous  peoples  in  project  planning, 
implementation, and monitoring. 
(ii)  Formulate specific activities to improve social and economic conditions of these 
groups, taking into account their own views in the process. 
(iii)  Ensure  that  project  interventions  are  culturally  sensitive  and  do  not  in  any 
manner adversely affect their cultural identities and customs. 
(iv)  Promote  the  participation  of  women  in  decision  making  and  project 
implementation.  
 
6.  The above will provide the basis for the formulation of IPDPs of subprojects, if required.  
 
D.  Procedure for Preparing an IPDP 
 
7.  An IPDP is an integral part of the project design and includes provisions for project 
implementation, monitoring, and evaluation. An IPDP will consist of (i) preliminary screening, (ii) 
social impact assessment, (iii) mitigation measures, (iv) development assistance, and (v) project 
monitoring. 
 
8.  Preliminary  Screening.  The  executing  agency  (EA)  and  project  design  and 
implementation  consultants  will  visit  all  tsunami-affected  coastal  communities,  which  come 
under these two projects. During these visits, the EA and project design and implementation 
consultants will arrange public meetings with village leaders of Vedda communities to collect 
information about their views on project activities and how they address their needs.  
 
9.  Social Impact Assessment. The screening process will identify indigenous peoples, 
their groups, community-based organizations, cultural traditions, and community structures. If 
required,  a  social  impact  assessment  (SIA)  will  be  prepared  to  gather  information  on  the 
population and its social, cultural, and economic conditions, and the anticipated social, cultural, 
and economic impacts of the projects, both positive and negative. Focus group meetings will be 
held with community leaders and groups of men and women who have been severely affected 
and with those who live in the “zones of influence” of the proposed subprojects. If the SIA 
indicates that the subprojects would significantly threaten cultural practices and sources of 
livelihood of indigenous peoples, every attempt will be made to avoid or minimize such adverse 
impacts in the formulation and implementation of IPDPs. 
 
10.  Mitigation Measures. All affected Vedda households will be helped to improve their 
living standards without exposing their communities to disintegration. As vulnerable groups, they 
are entitled to receive special assistance not only to restore and improve their income and 
livelihood, but also to maintain their distinct cultural identity. If the subproject impacts are not 
significant and if they could be addressed by resettlement plans that will be prepared according 
to the agreed-on resettlement framework, “specific actions” could be built into resettlement

Appendix 15  113
plans to safeguard their entitlements. This decision will depend on the severity of impacts on 
them.  
 
11.  Development Assistance. In case a subproject impacts on Veddas, they are entitled to 
all assistance that will be provided to other tsunami-affected communities. They are entitled to 
receive  support  to  continue  their  distinct  living  arrangements  and  to  maintain  their  unique 
cultural system.  
 
12.  Land Acquisition. In case of land acquisition, Veddas are entitled to receive land in 
compensation for the acquired land. As indigenous peoples, they will have traditional land 
rights. The absence of land titles will not bar indigenous peoples from receiving compensation. If 
they prefer cash for land, they are entitled to receive cash compensation for land and housing. 
Their compensation entitlements will be the same that are listed in the approved resettlement 
framework in Appendix 12. Land-for-land or cash-for-land compensation will be paid before any 
subproject activity is started.  
 
E.  Consultation and Information Disclosure 
 
13.  The tsunami-affected indigenous peoples will be informed and consulted when an IPDP 
is prepared to enable them to benefit from the project and to protect them from any potential 
adverse impacts of the project. Therefore, consultation with and participation of the communities 
and their continuous interaction with local government officials will be an integral part of the 
formulation of an IPDP. The plan will be translated into the local language and made available 
before implementation by the EA with the assistance of NGOs. 
 
14.  Local  communities  and  community-based  organizations  (CBOs)  will  help  implement 
IPDPs, and all issues in dispute will be resolved through consultation and facilitation. The EA 
will ensure that adequate funds wil be available for consultation and facilitation 
 
F.  Institutional Framework  
 
15.  The EA and implementing agencies (IAs) of subprojects will be responsible for the 
overall  coordination,  financing,  implementation,  and  monitoring  IPDPs.  The  EA  will  make 
arrangements  to  appoint  officials  who  are  sensitive  to  indigenous  peoples  issues  and 
knowledgeable in their ways of life, culture, and practices to plan and implement IPDPs. The EA 
will ensure that the consultants hired to plan and implement IPDPs are familiar with ADB’s 
indigenous peoples policy and safeguards. The EA or IA will engage an anthropologist to 
examine the Veddas’ needs and to recommend how to accommodate such needs under the 
projects. 
 
G.  Budgetary Provisions  
 
16.  The EA of a subproject will provide sufficient resources to formulate an IPDP if the 
subproject will have any impact on the Veddas. It will implement the IPDP through district, 
divisional and local agencies and with the assistance with NGOs. A detailed budget will be 
prepared by the EA by taking into account all the activities associated with the formulation and 
implementation of IPDPs. Each IPDP will have its own budget. Such budgets will be an integral 
part of the project cost, and will be made available during implementation.

114  Appendix 15   
H.  Monitoring and Evaluation 
 
17.  A set of monitoring indicators will be included in each IPDP, to be reviewed during 
project implementation. Internal monitoring will be done by the PMU, along with preparation of 
semiannual progress reports. An external independent monitor will monitor the progress of the 
implementation of IPDPs. Reporting and monitoring formats will be prepared for an effective 
internal and external monitoring. These reports will be submitted to Resident Mission for review 
and comments.  
 
18.  Each IPDP will be submitted by the EA to the Resident Mission for review and approval 
before  any  subproject  activity  is  started.  This  particularly  applies  to  land  acquisition  and 
compensation payments.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Sri Lanka:  
The two-decades-long conflict and the recent tsunami have severely affected the communities in these areas. Loss of 
life, livelihoods, incomes, and property have resulted in significant socioeconomic and psychological stress. In the 
conflict-affected areas essential investments have not been made for a long time.  
 
The project will provide shelter and reestablish vital services such as roads, fisheries and irrigation infrastructure, 
health and educational facilities, water supply, agricultural support services and institutions to revive economic 
activities leading to employment, income generation, rehabilitation of displaced persons, and restoration of social 
stability in these areas.  
 
Improvement  of  services  and  infrastructure  will  also  encourage  people  to  return  to  their  original  villages  and 
settlements. With this end in view, the project will also strengthen health and educational facilities while strengthening 
local level institutions. Community based organizations will be established and supported, saving will be encouraged, 
women will be made more self-reliant, microcredit will be introduced, and recreational facilities will be provided.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: Poverty Intervention 
In the North and East, the people affected by the conflict are especially vulnerable due to gender, age, disability, and 
general breakdown in their traditional livelihood systems. Internally displaced people who wish to return to their areas 
of origin need support in reestablishing their homes and their livelihoods. Essential services such as schools, 
hospitals, clinics, water and power supply are lacking in these areas. Agricultural production has been adversely 
affected by the neglect of minor irrigation schemes. Surplus food production areas have become food deficit areas. 
Livestock numbers have declined. In general the region has suffered extensive dislocation and economic progress has 
been hampered. These problems have been further aggravated by the tsunami through loss of lives and property. 
Livelihoods especially of fishermen have been destroyed. The psychological trauma from the loss of lives has been 
tremendous.  
 
The people in the project areas face major challenges in terms of basic human needs: shelter, employment and 
livelihoods, access to services (education, health, agricultural support services, irrigation, markets, power supply), 
community based institutions.  
 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No  
 
Much of the project will be implemented through stakeholder consultation, using a bottom-up approach. Subproject 
formulation, design, and selection will be through community consultation. Local participation in the implementation of 
subprojects  will  be  encouraged  as  appropriate.  This  process  has  proven  highly  successful  in  other  ongoing 
rehabilitation projects in the North East.

128  Appendix 18 
 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: The conflict and the tsunami have resulted in a disproportionate increase 
in the number of women-headed households in the North East. To some extent this is also true in the South after the 
tsunami. This presents significant challenges in these communities where women traditionally have many other 
disadvantages. Both projects provide opportunities through various components, for both women and men, to restart 
and to initiate livelihood and enterprise activities. The projects will be proactive in identifying the women, households 
headed by women, war widows, etc. in the various communities who require training in production-related skills, 
business planning, marketing skills and access to credit and technical support to enable them to improve their 
economic strength and contribute to the enhanced well-being of their families. The projects will strengthen the capacity 
of women’s nongovernment organizations so that they can act as resource centers on gender awareness and assist in 
making appropriate investments to improve their livelihoods.

GENDER ACTION PLAN 
 
1.  The objectives of the gender action plan (GAP) are to promote and enable the equal 
participation of men and women stakeholders as agents and beneficiaries of the Tsunami-
affected Areas Rebuilding Project (TAARP) and the North East Community Restoration and 
Development Project II (NECORD-II). The GAP is based on the analysis1 that that women are 
disadvantaged and discriminated against in sociocultural, economic, and political spheres of life 
and are denied equal access to resources, services, and opportunities that would enable them 
to participate in, contribute to, and benefit fully from development  processes. TAARP and 
NECORD-II will encourage and support women’s increased participation in needs assessment 
and consultation and in planning and implementing activities in different sectors through the 
various components of both projects. The GAP will give particular attention to the following: 
 
(i)  equal  participation  of  women  and  men  in  urban  planning  and  village 
reconstruction and development activities and processes;  
(ii)  recovery of livelihood and economic activities for women and men, while paying 
special attention to the introduction of and support for livelihood and enterprise 
activities for war widows and female-headed households in the conflict-affected 
areas;  
(iii)  equal  access  of  women  and  men  to  infrastructure  activities  in  relation  to 
planning, construction, as users and in maintenance; and  
(iv)  involvement  of  women  and  men  in  environmental  management  and  coastal 
resource management.  
 
2.  The GAP will be implemented through the planned implementation mechanisms for 
TAARP and NECORD-II. The capacity of implementing agencies and units will be strengthened 
through training, and consultants and/or consulting agency services will be obtained, where 
necessary, to implement the GAP.
